search_result.title: American Idol winners: All 21 seasons ranked, worst to best
search_result.text:
You can say this for ‚ÄúAmerican Idol‚Äù: More than 20 years in, it‚Äôs still worth arguing about.

Should Kris Allen have prevailed over Adam Lambert? Queen would like a word.

Carrie Underwood over Bo Bice? We loved the hair, Bo, but sorry, Carrie was the rightful empress.

Lee DeWyze instead of Crystal Bowersox? Our blood pressure spikes just recalling that travesty.

And there are no words for the injustice that was ousting Jennifer Hudson in seventh place during the show's third season. But the "Idol" spotlight still allowed for the discovery of Hudson's talent and eventual mega-stardom.

Though the ‚ÄúIdol‚Äù hitmaking machine now creaks rather than churns out superstars, the platform is still unparalleled when compared to its singing competition peers.

We‚Äôve ranked the 21 ‚ÄúAmerican Idol‚Äù winners based primarily on sheer talent, but with an obvious nod toward their success after the show (new winner Iam Tongi excepted from that criteria).

Please, continue arguing.

Ranked, from worst to best: Every 'American Idol' winner's song (even Noah Thompson's 'One Day Tonight')

21. Lee DeWyze (2010)

Despite his affable personality and gruff coffeehouse croon, DeWyze lacked the undeniable spark and grit of Crystal Bowersox, the Janis Joplin incarnate who outrageously only placed second that season. ‚Äì Patrick Ryan

20. Chayce Beckham (2021)

Beckham impressed on the show with his passionate rendition of The Beatles‚Äô ‚ÄúBlackbird,‚Äù but his gravelly voice often conjured memories of Creed. And no, that‚Äôs not a good thing. But Beckham‚Äôs career plans reside in country ‚Äì his coronation song, ‚Äú23,‚Äù hit No. 1 on the Billboard country digital chart. ‚Äì Melissa Ruggieri

19. Laine Hardy (2019)

The Louisiana native, who was arrested and charged with secretly recording an ex-girlfriend, rose through the ‚ÄúIdol‚Äù ranks with his Elvis Presley-style croon and stage persona. But outside the throwback shtick, the husky-voiced Hardy has struggled to stand out from other past winners who have charted similar country/bluegrass terrain. ‚Äì

18. Noah Thompson (2022)

Between his casual style and bashful demeanor ‚Äì and, of course, the reality that "Idol" voters tend to favor young white men who can be presented as harmless heartthrobs ‚Äì Thompson was the natural choice as victor this season. The judges praised his performance of Bruce Springsteen's "I'm on Fire" during the finale, a toothless rendition that nonetheless achieved its goal: squealing girls in the audience. ‚Äì

17. Nick Fradiani (2015)

It felt like the buff singer was the next breakout star after his victory song, the catchy singalong ‚ÄúBeautiful Life,‚Äù dented the charts. But his 2016 debut album, ‚ÄúHurricane,‚Äù fared poorly and an independently released EP in 2017, ‚ÄúWhere We Left Off,‚Äù also failed to produce liftoff. Still, Fradiani continues to make music and dabbled in acting with a turn in the national tour of ‚ÄúA Bronx Tale‚Äù (2019-2020). ‚Äì Ruggieri

16. Taylor Hicks (2006)

Given the top three talent pool of Season 5 ‚Äì which also included Katharine McPhee and Elliott Yamin ‚Äì it's still a bit stunning that the overwrought Alabamian prevailed. But the "Soul Patrol" proved a mighty engine and Hicks successfully parlayed his win into a platinum-selling self-titled debut album in 2006, a Broadway stint and tour (playing the Teen Angel in "Grease") and a modest residency in Las Vegas. ‚Äì Ruggieri

15. Kris Allen (2009)

Some were shocked when the innocuous Allen triumphed over the bold flamboyance of Adam Lambert during Season 8 of ‚ÄúIdol‚Äù ‚Äì not that it hindered Lambert‚Äôs future. But more than Allen‚Äôs couple of hits (‚ÄúNo Boundaries,‚Äù ‚ÄúLive Like We‚Äôre Dying‚Äù), his win ushered in the era of nondescript male singer-songwriters armed with guitars and crooked grins. ‚Äì Ruggieri

14. Trent Harmon (2016)

Harmon‚Äôs boyish face and soft-spoken demeanor masked a deceptively brawny set of pipes, which were put to best use on an enchanting cover of Sia‚Äôs ‚ÄúChandelier.‚Äù Harmon signed to Big Machine Records (Taylor Swift's former label) post-"Idol," finding minor success on the country charts with singles "Falling" and "There's a Girl." ‚Äì Ryan

13. Just Sam (2020)

A former subway busker, New York-bred Samantha Diaz stormed the (virtual) ‚ÄúIdol‚Äù stage with her unfiltered persona and pure singing talent. Her pandemic-season performance of Kelly Clarkson‚Äôs ‚ÄúStronger (What Doesn‚Äôt Kill You)," as well as a stunning duet with Lauren Daigle on ‚ÄúYou Say‚Äù solidified her deserved victory. The realities of the record business derailed her post-show album release, but she‚Äôs recently independently released the songs ‚ÄúAfricando‚Äù and ‚ÄúChange.‚Äù ‚Äì Ruggieri

12. Caleb Johnson (2014)

Johnson was the typically staid competition‚Äôs closest answer to Whitesnake and AC/DC, with squalling vocals and head-banging dynamism that have made him a hit with the legacy rock crowd in the years since his victory, touring with Meat Loaf's Neverland Express and Trans-Siberian Orchestra. ‚Äì Ryan

11. Iam Tongi (2023)

The Hawaiian-born 18-year-old captured hearts starting with his tear-inducing audition with James Blunt‚Äôs ‚ÄúMonsters,‚Äù which Tongi dedicated to his late father. His combination of a mellifluous voice and gentle, upbeat demeanor proved irresistible, but there is also no denying Tongi‚Äôs soul. His new single, the acoustic ballad ‚ÄúI‚Äôll Be Seeing You,‚Äù is a touching, honest debut. ‚Äì Ruggieri

10. Phillip Phillips (2012)

A soft-spoken guitar strummer who in his pre-‚ÄúIdol‚Äù life worked at his family‚Äôs pawn shop in Leesburg, Georgia, Phillips earned a significant bona fide: His coronation song, the Dave Matthews Band-esque ‚ÄúHome,‚Äù is the bestselling single in the show‚Äôs history, with more than 5 million sold. A spate of other hits (‚ÄúRaging Fire,‚Äù ‚ÄúGone, Gone, Gone‚Äù) preserved his momentum, and last month Phillips returned to the ‚ÄúIdol‚Äù stage for his 10th anniversary to play his new release, ‚ÄúLove Like That.‚Äù ‚Äì Ruggieri

9. Maddie Poppe (2018)

In a competition that favors blue-eyed crooners and power belters, Poppe was a refreshingly sophisticated pick: a raspy-voiced folk artist who could make you smile singing Disney‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Jungle Book‚Äù just as easily as she could rip your heart out with a Beach Boys cover. She‚Äôs one of the few recent ‚ÄúIdol‚Äù victors who you could legitimately call a ‚Äúsingular talent.‚Äù ‚Äì Ryan

8. Scotty McCreery (2011)

The resident male country star to graduate from the ‚ÄúIdol‚Äù laboratory ‚Äì like Season 6 winner Jordin Sparks, at only 17 ‚Äì the North Carolina native with a molasses-hued voice that belies his unassuming demeanor remains a prominent chart presence a decade after his Season 10 win. ‚ÄúFive More Minutes,‚Äù ‚ÄúThis Is It‚Äù and ‚ÄúIn Between‚Äù are among his recent country chart-toppers, while ‚ÄúSame Truck,‚Äù his fifth studio album released last year, spawned the George Strait tribute tune, ‚ÄúDamn Strait.‚Äù ‚Äì Ruggieri

7. Candice Glover (2013)

Whether she was covering Ben E. King, Aretha Franklin, or The Cure (on tearful standout ‚ÄúLovesong‚Äù), the Beaufort, South Carolina, native brought unmatched vulnerability and powerhouse vocals to every single performance. Her recording career post-‚ÄúIdol,‚Äù too, is filled with stirring ballads that have been sadly ignored by radio. ‚Äì Ryan

6. David Cook (2008)

With his pleasantly raspy voice and a knack for melody and unearthing lesser-known versions of hits to cover on the show (e.g., Whitesnake's "Day Tripper," Chris Cornell's "Billie Jean"), the Season 7 winner ‚Äì over angelic David Archuleta ‚Äì skyrocketed to success. His victory song, the inspirational pop-rock anthem ‚ÄúThe Time of My Life,‚Äù and its follow-up, ‚ÄúLight On,‚Äù each sold more than a million copies and showcased his musical worldview (Collective Soul, Foo Fighters and the Goo Goo Dolls counted among his inspirations). In 2021, Cook‚Äôs music delved into his struggle with anxiety on the independently released EP, ‚ÄúThe Looking Glass.‚Äù ‚Äì Ruggieri

5. Ruben Studdard (2003)

Studdard‚Äôs smooth, velvety vocals were the perfect complement to runner-up Clay Aiken‚Äôs earnest pop theatrics, with standout performances of Stevie Wonder and Dionne Warwick classics, and a respectable career as a gospel/R&B hitmaker in years to follow. ‚Äì Ryan

4. Jordin Sparks (2007)

The show‚Äôs youngest winner at 17 (by two months compared to McCreery), the sweet-smiling Sparks found immediate success a few months after her victory with a pair of Billboard top 10 hits: ‚ÄúTattoo‚Äù and ‚ÄúNo Air,‚Äù her duet with a pre-scandal Chris Brown. Broadway (‚ÄúIn the Heights‚Äù) and film (‚ÄúSparkle‚Äù) expanded Sparks‚Äô reach, but in recent years she‚Äôs concentrated more on motherhood with a few career moves ‚Äì the 2020 holiday album ‚ÄúCider & Hennessey,‚Äù her 2021 participation in ‚ÄúThe Masked Dancer‚Äù ‚Äì sprinkled in. ‚Äì Ruggieri

3. Fantasia Barrino (2004)

Barrino‚Äôs sultry, soulful rendition of George Gershwin‚Äôs ‚ÄúSummertime‚Äù might be the all-time greatest performance to ever hit the ‚ÄúIdol‚Äù stage. The R&B artist‚Äôs elastic vocals and deep well of emotion will continue to serve her well, as she reprises her role as Celie from the Broadway musical ‚ÄúThe Color Purple‚Äù for next year‚Äôs star-studded movie adaptation. ‚Äì Ryan

2. Carrie Underwood (2005)

It feels like 100 lifetimes ago that a pouffy-haired Underwood blasted us off our couches with her rendition of Heart‚Äôs ‚ÄúAlone‚Äù during her Season 4 run to the top. And remember her small-town country-girl proclamation that she‚Äôd never been on an airplane prior to her ‚ÄúIdol‚Äù audition? Six massive headlining tours, an aerial-filled Las Vegas residency, a lot of leg bronzer and 65 million-plus album sales later (she‚Äôs the top-selling artist in the ‚ÄúIdol‚Äù franchise), Underwood has earned a few frequent flier rewards. ‚Äì Ruggieri

1. Kelly Clarkson (2002)

There‚Äôs a reason Clarkson goes viral every other week with her adventurous and breathtaking ‚ÄúKellyoke‚Äù covers on the daytime talk show ‚ÄúThe Kelly Clarkson Show.‚Äù The Texas native is so effortlessly charming and in control of her instrument, with an outsized personality and even larger voice that bring all the ferocity and drama you want from a top 40 hit (of which she has nearly two dozen). Frankly, our lives would suck without Clarkson, who is the brightest star ‚ÄúIdol‚Äù has and will likely ever produce. ‚Äì Ryan

search_result.title: American Idol: Estero's Casey Bishop wows Luke Bryan at Sunday ...
search_result.text:
Luke Bryan‚Äôs calling it already. He‚Äôs predicting this year‚Äôs winner of ‚ÄúAmerican Idol."

It‚Äôs Estero teen Casey Bishop.

‚ÄúI think she‚Äôs the damn winner of ‚ÄòAmerican Idol,‚Äô‚Äù Bryan said, moments after Bishop auditioned Sunday on the TV singing competition. ‚ÄúPeriod. It‚Äôs evident.‚Äù

Later, Bryan added this: ‚ÄúWow, y‚Äôall. My body has been tingling for 10 minutes. She is a MASSIVE star.‚Äù

Bishop, 16, sang two songs for the judges: The jazz standard ‚ÄúMy Funny Valentine‚Äù and a slowed-down, bluesy version of M√∂tley Cr√ºe‚Äôs ‚ÄúLive Wire.‚Äù

Afterward, judges Bryan, Katy Perry and Lionel Richie seemed stunned by what they‚Äôd just heard.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt think anybody would get close to Alejandro‚Äôs audition, as far as me being just, like, dipped in Disney and sparkles and flowers and doves,‚Äù Bryan said, referring to 2019 finalist Alejandro Aranda. ‚ÄúAnd that‚Äôs what your audition was for me.

‚ÄúI wrote ‚ÄòTop 10, def‚Äô on the M√∂tley Cr√ºe song, and then you just did ‚Äî I don‚Äôt even know what the heck just happened just then (with 'My Funny Valentine').‚Äù

Previously: Estero teen Casey Bishop is ready to rock out on her 'American Idol' audition

Even more impressive: It was Bishop‚Äôs first time singing for an audience other than her friends, her high school chorus and school talent shows.

‚ÄúI have no experience performing,‚Äù Bishop said on the show. ‚ÄúMost people here seem to have lots of performing experience. I‚Äôm kinda intimidated.

‚ÄúThe only places I sing are literally my bathroom. I put my song on, pick up my brush and then I just go for it, like in the mirror. I just literally pretend that I‚Äôm onstage.‚Äù

Now Bishop doesn‚Äôt have to pretend anymore. And ‚ÄúAmerican Idol‚Äôs‚Äù judges predict great things for her future.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre gonna enjoy watching you grow,‚Äù Richie said. ‚ÄúRight here in front of us. ‚Ä¶ The sky is the limit.‚Äù

Related coverage:Did Ben Allen make it to 'The Voice' finale?

Perry ‚Äî a longtime idol of Bishop‚Äôs ‚Äî felt the same way.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre really, really, really good,‚Äù Perry said. ‚ÄúAnd I love that nobody knows that you can sing besides you and couple of your friends and your hairbrush, probably. I mean, a lot of hair, a lot of brushing, a lot of microphone time.‚Äù

After her audition, Bishop scored a golden ticket to perform again on the show for Hollywood Week, which starts March 21.

‚ÄúOh my god!‚Äù a tearful Bishop exclaimed to the judges after they all said ‚Äúyes‚Äù to moving her to the next round. ‚ÄúThank you so much!‚Äù

Minutes later, she ran out the doors of the audition room with her mother and yelled, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to Hollywood!‚Äù

Bishop ‚Äî who was 15 when she filmed her California audition in November ‚Äî landed on the show after taking part in virtual auditions.

‚ÄúI just auditioned for some producers on my mom‚Äôs iPad, and it went great,‚Äù she told The News-Press and Naples Daily News last week. ‚ÄúHere I am (laughs).‚Äù

Performing on "American Idol" meant the world to her, she said. The aspiring rock 'n' roller sings, plays guitar and adores M√∂tley Cr√ºe, The Pretty Reckless and 90s grunge bands.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what I‚Äôve always wanted to do and had my eyes on and my mind on: Just singing and making music and singing on the stage, rocking out," said the sophomore at Fort Myers' Center for the Arts at Cypress Lake High School. ‚ÄúI just really want to be on the stage. I love it. I didn‚Äôt know I could love it that much.‚Äù

search_result.title: Which Florida football recruits will see their stock rise this fall?
search_result.text:
Ahmad Moten wasn't a household name at this time a year ago.

In fact, the 6-foot-3, 325-pound Cardinal Gibbons defensive tackle didn't have any offers.

Fast forward 12 months and Moten is preparing for his freshman year at the University of Miami. He announced his decision in February, capping a frantic few months of recruiting that saw Florida, LSU, Oklahoma, Tennessee, West Virginia and many others offer him scholarships.

Moten broke out last fall and his strong start to the season propelled him to being considered one of the top recruits in the state.

What happened to Moten happens every year and this year will be no exception.

Recent:What are the biggest high school football games in Florida this season?

More from Jon Santucci:Trinity Christian running back Treyaun Webb commits to Florida

Free:Check out our statewide high school football recruiting newsletter!

A handful of players who either went overlooked during the recruiting process (so far) or are late bloomers will impress colleges with a strong start to their senior season.

USA Today Florida Network reporters picked players from around the state who could see their recruitment pick up this fall.

Big Bend

Ayden Fryar, Lincoln

Lincoln senior quarterback Ayden Fryar is stepping into some big shoes this fall. He takes over the starting position following Perry Fisher, who is now at Maryland and was an All-Big Bend first-team offense selection. Fryar did play in all, but one game for Lincoln and leaned heavily on his running backs. Early on in the preseason, Fryar has immensely improved on his passing game and is throwing with speed and precision. Trojans head coach Jimmie Tyson has spoken about how impressed he is on the quarterback's improvement over the summer. In a program like Lincoln, that has a lot of eye on it from colleges, expect Fryar to see his recruitment rise big time. ‚Äî Jack Williams, Tallahassee Democrat

Bradenton-Sarasota

Maddox Marchbank, Sarasota

Marchbank is one of the area's most versatile players. The 6-foot-3, 270 pounder can play guard, defensive tackle and is the long snapper for the Sailors. Offered by Seton Hill University, Marchbank had seven sacks and 55 tackles (22 for a loss) last year on the defensive line. Sailors coach Brody Wiseman said, "We see him as a collegiate talent on either side of the ball depending on the need of the teams recruiting him." Additionally, Marchbank is a Khol's 4-star rated long snapper. At the camp he displayed "solid mechanics and scored on 9 of his 12 long snaps with an average snap time of .77 seconds," according to coaches there. ‚Äî Dennis Maffezzoli, Sarasota Herald-Tribune

Daytona Beach

Ashton Bracewell, Flagler Palm Coast

Flagler Palm Coast's senior linebacker ticks a lot of physical boxes ‚Äî he's 6-foot-4, 215 pounds and athletic in coverage as a converted safety. Bracewell had a hand in 55 tackles last season, adding three sacks, three pass breakups, two forced fumbles and an interception. He collected five verbal offers in the spring ‚Äî Akron, Eastern Kentucky, Florida Atlantic, Navy and Toledo. A fast start could increase his Division I opportunities, and improve his standing on the recruiting boards of those respective schools. ‚Äî Chris Boyle, Daytona Beach News-Journal

Fort Lauderdale

Kamari Moulton, Cardinal Gibbons

The Chiefs senior is very underrated. A legitimate 5-foot-11 190-pound balanced running back with speed and strength and only one Power 5 offer. But overcoming obstacles is nothing new to this young man. Kamari lost his mother to COVID-19 in the beginning the 2021 playoff run that ended with him powering an explosive Cardinal Gibbons offense to another state championship. He‚Äôs coming off a junior season with 1,075 rushing yards and 18 touchdowns, which earned him all-state honors. A huge senior campaign could result in Moulton grabbing his third state championship ring and finding himself a home at power 5 school. ‚Äî Quinten Lambert, Special to the USA Today Network

Fort Myers

Spencer Yeager, Fort Myers

The 6-foot-2, 180-pound linebacker is a critical player coming back for Sam Sirianni Jr.'s defense. He led the team with 90 tackles last year along with a sack, two interceptions, and a fumble recovery. With the Green Wave looking to bounce back from a 5-4 season below their standards, Yeager could be a player who will get looks. And with the Greenies facing off against North Fort Myers, St. Thomas Aquinas and Dunbar in three of their first four games, Yeager will be facing off against some elite talent early on in the season. ‚Äî Dustin Levy, Fort Myers News-Press

Gainesville

Tyler Jefferson, Lake City Columbia

After leading Hawthorne to the Class 1A state title game in 2021, Tyler Jefferson elected to reunite with Demetric Jackson at Lake City Columbia for his senior campaign. Jefferson played under Jackson at Fort White in his freshman and sophomore seasons, before Jackson took the head coaching job at Columbia. In terms of recruiting, Jefferson committed to Central Michigan after fielding offers from Florida Atlantic, Florida State, Kentucky and Maryland, among others. However, with the keys to the electric Columbia offense in his hands, don't be surprised if more Power 5 offers come rolling in for Jefferson. ‚Äî Ainslie Lee, The Gainesville Sun

Jacksonville

Desirrio Riles, University Christian

At UC, they call him "Oo," and this year, the 225-pound QB-turned-linebacker could be leaving opponents saying "Ow." A three-year starter at quarterback for UC, Riles has bulked up significantly and intends to play this year in an all-purpose athlete role, primarily linebacker on defense and tight end on offense. Even while lining up at QB as a junior, he contributed on defense with 31 tackles, and now that he's dedicating more time to the defensive side of the ball, look for recruiters to take notice. Michigan and Boston College are among his offers since the start of spring practice. --Clayton Freeman, Florida Times-Union

Miami

Corey Washington, Miami Central

Washington is one of the most explosive players in South Florida. Corey is 5‚Äô7 150-pounds, which is small for colleges to recruit him. But Corey is out on a mission to prove those recruiters wrong. In opinion of many coaches in Miami-Dade, Corey is the scariest player in the county. Last year, he had a whopping six return touchdowns along with 500-plus all-purpose yards. Corey has elite quickness that causes players to simply slip right off him and burst to get him inside the end zone frequently. This offseason, he excelled with national power 7v7 team Defcon. He was used primarily in the slot and at running back, where he put up massive numbers throughout the 7v7 season. With Miami Central graduating senior receivers, look for Corey to put up massive numbers at receiver and the return game. ‚Äî Quinten Lambert, Special to the USA Today Network

Naples

Guerschom Guerrier, Lely

Guerrier, a running back for the Trojans, is one of the most highly-regarded players in the area by opposing coaches. The bruising running back went for 1,112 yards and 10 touchdowns last season and had five 100-plus yard games. Guerrier has the face the unfortunate reality of not being on a team that's used to winning, having just one winning season in the past five years. Consider Guerrier as one who has flown under the radar for years, with the potential for that to change this season. ‚Äì Alex Martin, Naples Daily News

Northeast Florida

T.J. Lawrence, Fleming Island

One year ago, Lawrence was lining up at tight end for Fleming Island, on his way to a season of three receptions for 44 yards. Now, he's added plenty of muscle (6-6, 285 pounds) and moved inside to offensive tackle. The result: Fast-increasing attention from college recruiters. During the spring, Lawrence picked up more than a dozen offers, including Georgia Tech and USF. If he demonstrates to recruiters that he's making the O-line adjustment smoothly, expect more offers to arrive in the coming months. --Clayton Freeman, Florida Times-Union

Northwest Florida

Jayce Brown, Choctawhatchee

The athletic ability was always there for Brown, but Choctaw's 0-8 campaign his sophomore year did the 6-foot, 170-pound wideout no favors. Come 2021, Jesse Winslette arrived under center and first-year head coach Frank Beasley committed to the vertical attack. The result was a 6-4 campaign and 30 receptions for 558 yards and eight touchdowns for Brown. Credit the breakthrough to his hands (zero drops in 2021), his post routes, his situational awareness when the ball's in the air. Simply put, the guy makes plays and is best on deep routes, as evidenced by his 18.6 yards per catch. Kansas State became the first Power 5 school to offer Brown this past June, just the first in what should be many high-profile offers. Winslette to Brown for 6. Get used to that. ‚Äî Seth Stringer, NWF Daily News

Orlando

Asaad Waseem, Ocoee

This is as deep a talent pool as Orlando has seen in a decade, so there was a plethora of choices. Ocoee already has two Power Five commits ‚Äî safety Zachary Tobe and edge rusher Calvin Smith, both of whom are planning to head to Illinois. Waseem, a newcomer to the program after stints at Wekiva and West Orange, already claims 18 Division I offers, but he is yet to take any official visits to date. The 6-foot, 170-pound slot receiver caught 36 passes for 463 yards, complementing Oklahoma signee Jayden Gibson last fall. ‚Äî Chris Boyle, Daytona Beach News-Journal

Palm Beach

Jayden Parrish, Atlantic

A defensive roster heavy with seniors and juniors limited Parrish's playing time last season, but a strong offseason signaled a breakout junior year was in the works. Atlantic's summer camp tour included stops at the campuses of Auburn and University of Alabama-Birmingham ‚Äì and two MVP awards for the 6-2, 210-pound Parrish after catching coaches' attention with his agility and quickness. This could also be Parrish's year to dominate at his second position, running back, now that the Eagles have graduated Corey Reddick and Omari Mitchell, who combined for 2,278 yards in 2021. ‚Äî Emilee Smarr, The Palm Beach Post

Pasco

Tayshaun Balmir, Pasco

Not familiar with the name? You might want to be if you‚Äôre a Pasco County high school football fan. Balmir isn‚Äôt a name you‚Äôd recognized from the couple of seasons because he didn‚Äôt play at Pasco his sophomore and junior years. His six-carry, 178-yard performance in the spring against Wesley Chapel Cypress Creek, however, was an eye opener. He has legitimate track speed and is difficult to bring down in open space. Offers? He doesn‚Äôt have one, but a strong start could change that. ‚Äî Andy Villamarzo, Special to the USA Today Florida Network

Pensacola

Demontrae Gaston, Pensacola Catholic

The Crusaders were dealt a bad hand when four-star sophomore Koby Howard suffered a broken tibia during a summer camp visit at Miami. With the standout wide receiver possibly out for the 2022 season, Gaston stands to see more touches as Catholic enters its second season in the spread. The 6-1, 200-pound junior wideout is coming off a year where he snatched 40 catches for 596 yards and two touchdowns. "I think of him as more of an all-purpose receiver because he'll make you miss and he runs well, too. He's really going to be big for us," Crusaders head coach Matt Adams said. Gaston currently has offers from Georgia Tech and Bethune-Cookman. ‚Äî Patrick Bernadeau, Pensacola News Journal

St. Augustine

Arion Stith, Bartram Trail

Last season saw a slew of breakout performers in St. Johns County, including Creekside offensive tackle Matt McCoy (Miami signee), Nease wide receiver Dom Henry (BYU) and Nease linebacker Ben Bogle (Southern Illinois). Perhaps the 6-foot-3, 240-pound Stith can follow suit. Bartram Trail's staff has high hopes for the interior rusher, a converted nose guard. "He's really aggressive and quick. He's going to give opposing O-lineman fits," Bears head coach Darrell Sutherland said. ‚Äî Chris Boyle, St. Augustine Record

Space Coast

Cameron Mills, Viera

Mills has offers from a handful of Division I schools, including USF and Marshall. He recently added cornerback to his running back duties, and it is as a defender that he is being recruited. As he displays the skills and speed his 6-foot body possesses ‚Äì Mills sprints and high jumps in the spring ‚Äì his recruiting could shift into a higher gear. -- Brian McCallum, Florida Today

Tampa-St. Petersburg

DL Antonio Henley

It isn‚Äôt like the Gaither defensive lineman is an unknown commodity at this point, but the sophomore‚Äôs stock could soar at the beginning of the season. Coming off a strong freshman campaign that saw Henley notch eight sacks and add 31 tackles, Henley is lightning-quick off the ball and uses his feet and leverage well at the point of attack. Not to mention Gaither head coach Kirk Karsen believes Henley is the best defensive tackle he‚Äôs seen in the area. That‚Äôs saying something. ‚Äî Andy Villamarzo, Special to the USA Today Network

Treasure Coast

Ryland Hauser, Jensen Beach

One year ago, Hauser was far from a name that would be considered as a Division I prospect. Utilized on both sides of the ball for the Falcons, Hauser had good size but had yet to flourish in his career entering the offseason. After hard work to fill out into a frame that sits at 6-foot-5, 225 pounds, Hauser concentrated on becoming a dynamic threat as a hybrid tight end/receiver. After a summer of camps in which he displayed the ball skills and the speed colleges like at his height, Hauser first picked up an an offer from Warner University but made headlines locally in July when Mississippi State offered him. Hauser has since added an offer from North Alabama and is a prime candidate to add more offers with a quick start to the season for a Jensen Beach program that should be much improved from 2021. ‚Äî Bryan Cooney, TCPalm

search_result.title: America needs immigrants to solve its labor shortage | CNN Business
search_result.text:
New York CNN ‚Äî

Immigration has long been a political football in the United States. But If you‚Äôre wondering why America‚Äôs labor shortage persists nearly three years into the Covid pandemic, it‚Äôs in part because America doesn‚Äôt have enough immigrants.

Immigrants are vital to the US economy and fill thousands of US jobs ‚Äì jobs many Americas don‚Äôt want to do. In 2020, the processing of legal immigrant worker visas stopped and only picked up towards the end of 2021.

And by the end of last year there were close to 2 million fewer working-age immigrants in the United States than there would have been if pre-pandemic immigration continued unchanged, according to new research from the University of California, Davis.

‚ÄúPart of the reason why there are so many vacancies and unfilled jobs in the US is that we are missing a whole lot of immigrants who regularly were coming before Covid,‚Äù said Giovanni Peri, the author of the UC Davis research and Director of the Global Migration Center.

The immigration debate has been reignited because of a surge at the US-Mexico Border. In March 2020, President Trump invoked Title 42 ‚Äì a law enacted during the pandemic to prevent the spread of Covid ‚Äì that has kept migrants and would-be asylum seekers out of the country.

Asylum seekers are legally able to work in the United States while they await their asylum cases. During that waiting period, those seeking asylum can apply for work permits ‚Äî a process that usually takes 180 days before they are authorized.

But the decrease in legal immigration over the last two years has hurt American businesses. Especially in industries that require lower skilled labor: construction, agriculture, and hospitality.

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt make up the losses unless we really change immigration laws and we allow more people every year to come in,‚Äù said Peri. ‚ÄúThe way in which we are catching up is that we are processing visas at the speed that it was done before Covid. So for a while there will be this gap.‚Äù

The lack of available workers has pushed wages higher ‚Äì fueling higher inflation. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said that in addition to an aging workforce there is a lack of foreign labor contributing to labor shortages.

‚ÄúThe combination of a plunge in net immigration and a surge in deaths during the pandemic probably accounts for about one-and-a-half million missing workers,‚Äù said Jerome Powell, Chairman of the Federal Reserve last month.

The ‚Äòbig impact‚Äô

The biggest impact comes to industries like construction, agriculture, and especially hospitality ‚Äì which are reliant on immigrant workers. Those types of industries had higher rates of unfilled jobs last year ‚Äì adding to existing labor shortages, according to UC Davis research. There are currently 10.3 million open jobs in the US ‚Äì 377,000 in construction and 1.6 million in hospitality. That number has been on the rise in recent months.

‚ÄúThe hospitality [sector] was employing a very large number of immigrants, 30%- 40% of the labor force in that sector was foreign born. And so you‚Äôre missing a lot of them, and potentially that is a big impact,‚Äù said Peri.

The restaurant industry has borne the brunt of the downturn in immigration. Slower service, restaurants closed for lunch, higher prices ‚Äì are all a result of labor shortages. And the restaurant industry is on track to grow by 14% in the next decade ‚Äì while the US-born workforce is expected to grow by just 10%, according to the National Restaurant Association. There will be more restaurant jobs than the US workforce can fill. Sixty percent of restaurant operators are facing staffing shortages limiting their operating capacity, according to National Restaurant Association.

But a new piece of legislation, ‚ÄúThe Essential Workers for Economic Advancement Act,‚Äù was introduced in the House earlier this year. The law would create a new visa program for workers in industries like hospitality.

‚ÄúImmigration reform is an economic necessity for the restaurant industry,‚Äù said Sean Kennedy, EVP of Public Affairs at the National Restaurant Association. ‚ÄúAllowing more legal immigration would be a win-win for employers in desperate need of employees and individuals seeking new opportunity.‚Äù

‚ÄúSkilled‚Äù workers

About 1 million of the 2 million potential immigrants who were lost during the pandemic were college educated, according to the UC Davis research. These workers would be considered ‚Äúhigh-skilled workers,‚Äù potentially coming to the US on H-1B specialty visas.

Those high-skilled workers are job multipliers. For each high-skilled worker ‚Äì 2.5 additional jobs are created, according to a report by UC Berkeley.

‚ÄúHigh skilled immigration is incredibly important,‚Äù said Adam Ozimek, chief economist at the Economic Innovation Group. ‚ÄúWe shouldn‚Äôt think of it as something that addresses short-term shortages ‚Äì although it can help ‚Äì but something that is really important for long run: innovation, productivity, growth, and health of the economy.‚Äù

Earlier this month, the American Farm Bureau Federation, along with 350 other agricultural groups, called on the Senate to pass an agricultural reform bill already passed by the House to address the farm labor crisis. Skilled foreign farm workers are the backbone of US agriculture and are traditionally in the US on H-2A seasonal visas, which saw its highest ever utilization rate this year, according to the Farm Bureau. But many in agriculture says it‚Äôs not enough and they still can‚Äôt find workers.

‚ÄúThe farm labor crisis is hindering production and contributing to food price inflation. We must address this workforce crisis threatening farms across the United States so our producers can continue to feed, clothe, and fuel our nation,‚Äù the letter to Senate leadership read.

But, according to the Department of Labor, 317,000 temporary H-2A jobs were certified last year, more than six times the number in 2005. But only 80% of those jobs certified resulted in a visa.

search_result.title: York-Adams 2020 football preview: Breaking down Division III teams
search_result.text:
It took a while for a clear favorite to emerge in YAIAA Division III last season.

Defending District 3 Class 2A champ York Catholic struggled through a down season. The rest of the usual contenders ‚Äî Delone Catholic, Littlestown, Bermudian Springs ‚Äî all got off to rough starts.

Eventually, it was Delone that emerged from an 0-3 start to run the table in the divisional schedule and claim the title.

All of those usual contenders have graduated some top stars but could be poised for strong seasons. Can anyone else emerge as a sleeper contender in this condensed season?

A few teams that have been bottom-feeders in recent years believe they will be much improved this fall.

Here are last year's standings.

Div. Overall

#*Delone Catholic 7 0 8 4

*Littlestown 6 1 7 4

Bermudian Springs

Key returnees: Savauri Shelton (FB/LB, sr.); Jay Martinez (QB/S, sr.); Mason Smith (G/DE, jr.); Ethan King (G/De, jr.); Ricky Pacana (RB/DB, jr.); Jonah Martin (LB, jr.); Jhonathan Balek (OL/DT, sr.); Matt Zelenski (WR/OLB, sr.).

Key losses: Joe Cooper (OL/DL); Carter King (OL/DL); J.J. Talley (WR/DB); Ryan Hart (RB/S); Carter Laughman (TE/DE).

The breakdown: The Eagles have a new head coach for the first time since the 1990s, but the program doesn't plan to change much.

New top man John Livelsberger spent more than a decade as an assistant under Jon DeFoe, who stepped down following a school-record 21 years leading the program.

Livelsberger said he's gotten consistent advice from DeFoe since being hired in February, especially on matters pertaining to playing during the pandemic. DeFoe remains the principal at Bermudian Springs.

"I don't need to rewrite the wheel. I know what success looks like," Livelsberger said. "I don't have to start from scratch. Obviously, I'm going to have my own touch here and there to bring a little life back to it.

"Jon has been integral as a sounding board. He's been a great resource, not just on how to run the football program but how to navigate an unknown time."

Bermudian Springs was a pillar of consistent success under DeFoe, earning a 152-78 record during his 21 seasons. The Eagles have made the District 3 playoffs nine times in the past 10 years, except for a 5-5 season in 2015.

Still, the Eagles haven't won a Division III title since 2014 and went 6-5 last season as injuries piled up on a young squad. They rebounded from a 1-2 start and beat York Catholic, but lost to rivals Delone Catholic and Littlestown.

But Bermudian brings back a lot of experience this year with eight returning starters, most of whom play on both sides of the ball.

Offensively, 6-foot-3 Jay Martinez will return at quarterback after missing the second half of last season with an ankle injury. 5-foot-11, 205-pound wrecking ball Savauri Shelton (352 yards, three touchdowns) could be primed for a big year at fullback after having to finish last season at quarterback due to the team's injuries.

The Eagles will need players to emerge at tailback and receiver, but they do bring back three starting offensive lineman. All-star outside linebacker Matt Zelenski will also be counted on as a receiver.

Shelton, Zelenski and Jonah Martin will lead the defense at linebacker after all posting more than 50 tackles last season. The Eagles gave up just 19 points per game last season, fourth-best in the low-scoring division.

"These guys are leaders amongst each other but they aren't afraid to dog on each other a bit," Livelsberger said of seniors like Shelton and Martinez. "That's the nice thing. These guys are friends, but they're also on each other to motivate each other because they know they depend on everyone for their success."

Biglerville

Key losses: Wyatt Fetters (OT); Josh Horner (QB); Colin Burke (RB/LB).

The breakdown: After a number of down years, the Canners believe this could be a breakout year under new head coach Brett Smyers.

A 2009 Biglerville grad, Smyers takes over for Alex Ramos, who stepped down after 10 seasons to take a teaching job at Greencastle-Antrim. Smyers was on Biglerville's coaching staff the past few seasons.

"With the great group of seniors we have, I have some pretty high expectations," Smyers said. "I feel like being in contention for that Division III title and making a playoff run, I think we have the ability to do that. If we get this offense together and execute at the level they're capable of, I don't see why we can't compete for that division title."

Biglerville split the division championship with Hanover and won a playoff game in 2015, but the program has struggled since then, winning just six combined games the past four seasons. The Canners took small steps forward last season by going 3-7.

Smyers noted that the 2015 team was made up of a strong senior class that suffered a 1-9 season its sophomore year before rebuilding. He hopes this year's team can do something similar.

"They were very selfless and were great leaders, and I have some of those similar attributes in this senior class as well," Smyers said. "Kids that are willing to do things for the greater good of the team. Kids that have stuck it out the past three years. They've been through the downs and we're looking to find some upside."

The key for Biglerville will be how its competes against the division's big four of Bermudian, Delone Catholic, Littlestown and York Catholic. The Canners lost to those programs by an average score of 33-8 last season, only keeping the game to Bermudian (21-12) under a double-digit deficit.

The Canners do have a lot of talent in the backfield this season. Kalen Sharrah (809 yards, 14 touchdowns) and Sam Hurda (845 yards, eight touchdowns) were both Division III coaches all-stars at running back and linebacker last season. Senior safety Zach Showers will step in as the starting quarterback.

They'll also get a major boost from the addition of senior Josh Fulton, who transferred from Delone after an incredible junior season. The 5-foot-9, 220-pound Fulton ran for over 1,000 yards and 15 touchdowns and racked up 135 tackles in 12 games for the Squires. He was named a first-team linebacker in the entire YAIAA by GameTimePA, an impressive feat for a Division III player.

"We already have a lot of great backs, and being able to rotate and have depth will only help our cause," Smyers said of Fulton. "He's just a great kid. Just his personality will fit well with our kids. He was raised and came up through our district, so he's friends with a lot of people on the team already."

Delone Catholic

Key returnees: Tate Neiderer (RB/LB, sr.); Nick Groft (OL/DT, sr.); Michael O'Brien (LB/RB, sr.); Cory Heffner (CB/RB, sr.); Dylan Zimmerman (WR/DB, sr.).

Key losses: Kevin Mowrey (QB); Joe Hernandez (RB/LB); Josh Fulton (RB/LB, transfer); Gabe Lee (WR/DB); Austin Staub (G/DT).

The breakdown: The Squires have been knocking on the door of a District 3 title for three years now.

2017's 8-2 team came four points away from an undefeated record and missed out on a two-team playoff bracket in Class 2A.

2018's squad was ridiculously dominant in 10 wins, but couldn't beat York Catholic in two attempts. They lost to the Irish in an overtime thriller in the District 3 title game.

Last year's team rolled off eight straight wins after an 0-3 start, and nearly pulled off a miraculous comeback to force overtime against Upper Dauphin in the District 3 title game. The attempt fell a few plays short.

Now, the Squires bump down to Class 1A, which only has a two-team playoff bracket. The drop down could also lead to success in the state playoffs, something the storied program has never experienced.

Of course, that's not the main focus right now. The Squires are happy just to be on the field.

"It's almost indescribable the sheer happiness we saw the first night we got together this summer," head coach Corey Zortman said. "Sometimes at a young age you don't appreciate the importance of sports to the high school experience."

Still, Zortman said his team still has the same goals as always, even with the uncertainty that still hangs over the season. He complimented the leadership that his seniors have shown.

"Our kids have a good perspective, and they'll be happy playing for a league championship or just playing the games," Zortman said. "But at the end of each season we want to win a league championship, qualify for districts and see what happens. All those goals are still there."

By the end of last season, Delone won games with a swarming defense that created turnovers and a rushing offense that racked up more than 250 yards per game on the ground. The Squires bring back seven starters on defense and six on offense but there are voids to fill.

Top tailback and Division III Offensive Player of the Year Joe Hernandez (more than 1,800 all-purpose yards, 14 touchdowns) graduated and bulldozing fullback-linebacker Josh Fulton (more than 1,000 rushing yards, 15 scores) transferred to his home district Biglerville. Cerebral quarterback Kevin Mowrey (now playing for Division III Widener) also graduated after throwing for 1,100 yards, 10 scores and just three interceptions.

Linebacker and reigning Division III Defensive Player of the Year Tate Neiderer will take a bigger role at running back after rushing for 657 yards and six scores last year. Fellow seniors Cory Heffner (wide receiver) and Michael O'Brien (guard) have switched positions and will contribute in the backfield.

Junior Coltyn Keller will likely be the team's starting quarterback, though sophomore defensive back Ryder Noel could compete with him for playing time.

"Coltyn has the edge because of his age, but I really like both kids," Zortman said. "I think either could play."

Senior captain Nick Groft is the lone returner on an offensive line that Zortman said will average about 6-feet and 225 pounds. Others kids who will compete for starting spots are Collin Snyder, Elijah Staub, Trent Giraffa, Sam Scovitch and Ryan King.

Other players to watch are corner-wideout Dylan Zimmerman, tight end-defensive end Wyatt Schussler and running back-linebacker Zack Fields.

Fairfield

Key returnees: Peyton Stadler (RB/LB, jr.); Jake Myers (QB/S, jr.); Jared Estes (G/DT, sr.); Nathan Mickley (K/P, sr.); Cody Valentine (RB/LB/DE, jr.); Nate Roberts (T/DE, sr.); Will Myers (LB/RB, jr.).

Key losses: Garrett Stadler (RB/LB); Brent Hamilton (TE/S).

The breakdown: The YAIAA's smallest school has shown incredible resilience in recent years.

The Knights almost didn't field a varsity team two years ago before Jason Thurston stepped up and took the head coaching job in late July.

They had a number of games last season where they suited up less than 20 healthy players.

They had schedule changes and a game canceled during that stretch.

So while playing during a pandemic is certainly a different and new challenge, Fairfield is used to dealing with uncertainty.

"It's the same kind of thing. It's frustrating and disappointing but there's no use getting upset about it," Thurston said of adapting to a condensed schedule. "We talk a lot about controlling what we can control, and there's a lot right now that we don't have control over.

"There was a point in the middle of last season when we had 16 healthy bodies. I asked the kids what they wanted to do, and they wanted to keep playing. They just want the opportunity to shine."

In early August, Thurston said the team expected to have 27 or 28 kids on the roster this season, a higher number than in recent years. He said he thought it was possible to get up to 30 by the start of the season.

Senior Jared Estes said the challenge of convincing his classmates to come out for football is that many kids in the school have said they don't want to play for a losing program.

However, there have been some positive signs. Fairfield only graduated three players after last season and had about 20 players regularly coming to voluntary workouts this summer, according to Thurston. He said those were the best numbers of his tenure.

"They always say we're losing, and the only thing I can say back to that is, 'The reason we're losing is you guys won't come out and help us,'" Estes said. "I just try to persuade them that it's a fun time, coach is really serious about what he's doing and it looks promising."

As a Class 1A program, Fairfield has played in three straight District 3 title games despite having losing records since the classification has just a handful of teams and a two-team bracket. That could be much more challenging this year with Delone and Steel-High dropping to 1A.

Still, the Knights believe they will be improved this season with a good amount of experience back. Junior Peyton Stadler had close to 100 tackles last season and will also start at running back. Junior Jake Myers will start at quarterback after playing in seven games last season.

"I told them it's going to be a process, and it's going to take time," Thurston said of building up the program. "They see for our program, this is going to be a year where we take big steps forward. I think they're humbled that we get that opportunity."

The breakdown: After taking some serious lumps last season, Hanover hopes to start building toward success this year with a young nucleus.

The Nighthawks also have a new coach.

Defensive coordinator Wil Ryder takes over the top job for Brandon Bishop, a former offensive coordinator who resigned after just two seasons. Hanover went 4-16 during that stretch.

A 2001 South Western grad who played for legendary Mustangs coach Don Seidenstricker, Rider hopes to bring relevance to a Nighthawks program that has struggled with participation numbers in recent years.

"The number of kids we have at the skill positions, we're pretty well loaded," Rider said. "We have a lot of talent. We're putting some pieces together, and we have some weapons."

Rider said the team had between 23 and 27 players showing up to offseason voluntary workouts and should have more than 30 players on the roster this season, an improvement from last season.

The Nighthawks went 1-9 last season, with its lone win coming against York County Tech. They particularly struggled on defense (38 points per game allowed) and running the ball (46 yards per game on the ground).

However, they were able to throw the ball with a couple of young players.

Quarterback Chase Roberts was very impressive as a freshman, throwing for more than 1,700 yards, 12 touchdowns and eight interceptions. Already 6-foot tall and with a cannon arm, Roberts led the division in passing yards and touchdowns and was named a second-team all-star by the coaches.

Top receiver Andre Caban graduated, but Mason Smith returns after catching 27 passes for more than 400 yards as a freshman last year. Junior Mitchell Brown and senior tight end Beau Gebhart could also be strong targets this season.

The key will be the team's blocking. Rider said the Nighthawks have low numbers on the offensive and defensive lines and will try some first-year players in those spots.

"The question is going to be: Can we keep Chase upright?," Rider said. "We have some struggled on the line but we're making progress. Some young guys have been stepping up. We're going to see how they respond."

Rider was on the team's coaching staff in 2015 when the Nighthawks enjoyed a 9-2 season and split the Division III title with Biglerville. That team's success was fueled by outstanding senior quarterback Kyle Krout, who went on to play basketball at Messiah College.

Rider said he believes Roberts can be just as good as Krout if he continues to progress. He added that the coaching staff has added a few pieces that could push the offense to another level.

"He is capable of taking us really far and surpassing what Krout was able to do," Rider said. "The one thing that really stood out last year, Chase would stand in there and know the defense was going to smack him in the face, and he kept going. There were times when I was legitimately concerned for his well-being, and he kept going. You don't see that a lot for a kid his age."

Key returnees: Jesse Hawk (RB/LB, sr.); Maxm Akins (LB, sr.); William Shoemaker (WR/DB, sr.); Dakota Kroft (OL/DT, sr.); Reese Huth (G/DL, sr.); Jeremy Gebhart (OT/DE, sr.); Bryce Redding (DE/T, jr.).

The breakdown: Mike Lippy is now the YAIAA's longest-tenured coach, but his team this year doesn't have the experience of past squads.

At YAIAA media day, Lippy said Littlestown has just three seniors who were starters last season. However, he said there are 12 seniors and 19 juniors on the roster who have the potential to be contributors this year.

He believes the program's young players have a lot of potential.

"We really feel there are a lot of juniors that are going to play a big part in our season this year," said Lippy, who is entering his 18th season leading the Bolts. "I'm really looking forward to working with the kids who are coming up and looking forward to a season."

Littlestown is coming off four straight playoff appearances and back-to-back 7-4 seasons. The Bolts were just 2-3 last season after getting shutout, 27-0, by Delone, but won five straight wins to make it back to the playoffs. They beat rivals York Catholic and Bermudian.

They featured a stingy defense (16 points allowed per game) and a balanced offense (197 yards on the ground, 96 through the air per game), but it's hard to know exactly what the Bolts will look like this year. Lippy declined to mention many players by name at media day, saying he wanted the team's players to earn the recognition.

Running back-linebackers Jesse Hall and Maxm Akins are senior leaders who were brought to media day by Lippy. William Shoemaker, Reese Huth, Dakota Kroft, Bryce Redding and Jeremy Gebhart were league coaches all-stars last season who are still on the roster. The bulk of the team's experience is on the line.

Shoemaker will be counted on at running back after rushing for 532 yards, picking up another 100 receiving and scoring six total touchdowns last year. The Bolts graduated most of the other players who produced at running back or receiver.

The Bolts will also need a new quarterback following the graduation of Zach Ressler. Lippy remained tight-lipped on the subject during media day, but said there's a competition between a few players.

"We don't have any information," Lippy said with a laugh in early August. "I will say it's an open competition. For the longest time my philosophy was (to go with) that senior, and this year's been different with that. The boy that is a senior wants to earn that position, and we have a junior who's up-and-coming and it's going to be quite a competition.

"They have a great attitude about competing with each other."

Lippy was also asked if he saw a favorite in the division this year. His response was as expected.

"Nope," he said while remaining straight-faced. "Anybody could win it this year. I think most of us have some kids coming back. We just hope that when Week 1 comes that we have a game, and the other stuff will fall into place."

York Catholic

Key returnees: Brennan Witman (WR/DB, sr.); Michael McBrairty (OL/DL, sr.); De'Kzeon Wyche (RB, sr.); Nicholas Andrasi (K, jr.); Landen Eckert (TE/LB, jr.); Levan McFadden (QB, so.).

Key losses: Noah Kiel (TE/LB); Ben Moir (WR/DB); Mitch Galentine (QB, transfer); Cormac Sterling (RB/LB); Matt Burnside (S); Seamus Landis (OL/DL); Jabbar Sease (DB); Hunter Karpulk (OLB).

The breakdown: The Irish are coming off a down season and will be very young, but that doesn't mean expectations aren't high.

Head coach Eric Depew sees big things for this year's group. He was candid when asked how he thinks his squad will compete against rivals Bermudian Springs, Delone Catholic and Littlestown.

"I think it will be us and then those three," Depew said. "I've got us at the top.

"I think we can have some success this year. We're hungry and have a lot of energy. We've got all these underclassmen and they're going to keep getting better."

York Catholic entered last year with high expectations after winning at least a share of the previous three division titles. The Irish were coming off a 12-1 season and District 3 title.

But even with a senior-heavy squad, things didn't go as expected in 2019. The Irish started 0-2 against strong York Suburban and Trinity squads and went 0-3 against the aforementioned Division III rivals, finishing 5-5.

"I was a little shocked," Depew said of last season. "That group was a part of those division championships, but some other teams were more physical than we were. I'm trying to teach that attitude this year."

The Irish bring back just three seniors this year, but Depew has high expectations for all of them. Michael McBrairty will anchor the offensive line. Star lacrosse player Brennan Witman could have a breakout year at receiver after dealing with injuries last season.

Then there's running back De'Kzeon Wyche, who rushed for 886 yards and eight touchdowns on 117 carries last season after transferring from York County Tech. The 6-foot, 190-pound Wyche hopes to be a highly-recruited player with a strong senior season.

"He looks like a man amongst boys," Depew said of Wyche. "He's got maturity, strength, speed, hunger. Just the eye of the tiger. It's gonna be fun."

The Irish have had strong defense the past few seasons (18 points per game allowed last season) and will look to continue that trend. Junior Landen Eckert and sophomore Nick Creisher will anchor that unit as linebackers.

Depew also pointed to sophomore lineman Ryan Tully, junior running back Andrew Adams and junior fullback-linebacker Ryan Kerchner as players that could have breakout years.

York Catholic will also be young at quarterback following the transfer of Mitch Galentine back to his home district, Eastern York. The Irish will go with sophomore Levan McFadden, who got playing time in five games last season and threw for 354 yards, seven touchdowns and one interception.

Depew had high praise for McFadden, comparing him to former York Catholic star dual-threat quarterback Hakeem Kinard, who went on to have a standout career as a defensive back for Division I St. Francis and earned some NFL tryouts.

"He's a Hakeem-type player," Depew said. "He's going to do some big stuff. He's got the leadership and confidence in himself. He's very coachable, and he's got the arm and running threat."

York County Tech

Key returnees: Bishop Banks (OL/DT, sr.); Josh Peters (LB, sr.); Hermery Nieves (RB/LB, sr.); Hunter Sommer (RB/DB, sr.); Kolby Courtney (C/DT, sr.).

Key losses: Ryan Gibson (QB); Luis Ortiz (OL/DL, sr.); James Wilmot (OL/DL); Logan Heilman (SE/DB, sr.); Michael Villalona (SE/DE, sr.).

The breakdown: Spartans coach Matt Glennon knows the wins haven't come for his team, but he does think there has been progress since he came back to the program last season.

He believes there has been a change in the culture at York Tech.

"I don't want to categorize it as despair, but the kids got used to a certain culture and expectation," Glennon said. "We've tried to change the expectation the last two yeas. Just little things like character and commitment."

The Spartans haven't won a game since 2016 and will enter this season on a 30-game losing streak. They lost games by an average score of 42-8 last season.

Glennon, who previously served as the team's coach from 2013 to 2014, knows the Spartans search for a win is the "elephant in the room." Still, he's proud of how his team competed last season.

"We were 0-10 last year and we had no issues at practice. Kids showed up every day," Glennon said. "In the games, never had an issue where kids quit. They were outmatched a lot, but they were picking each other up. It's neat to see the kids progress.

"We believe if we deal with the character, discipline and commitment, it will eventually translate to wins."

Glennon said he would estimate the Spartans have 35 to 40 kids on the roster. He said he was pleased that around 25 to 30 kids routinely showed up to voluntary workouts.

York County Tech will once again run the triple option on offense, which Glennon hopes will be difficult for other teams to game-plan for.

The team's top returning player is defensive tackle Bishop Banks, who was named a first-team Division III all-star by league coaches last season. Fullback Hermery Nieves rushed for 409 yards and three touchdowns last season despite suffering a season-ending injury in Week 4 last season.

Glennon said juniors Ja'mar Johnson and Cam Harpine will compete for time at quarterback.

Senior center Kolby Courtney praised his new head coach for instilling a new attitude in the team's players since last season.

"When coach Glennon came in, he raised the morale up a lot," Courtney said. "All the players seem a lot happier and actually want to go out and play."

The challenge: There is a lot of unknowns with Bermudian Springs this year as the team's run to the Class 3A championship game last year was propelled by a talented senior class.

Four-year starting quarterback Chase Dull was chief among them, but the team also lost standout linemen and linebackers to graduation.

"For us, the focus is just on us," head coach Jon DeFoe said.

The Eagles return senior linemen like Carter King and 6-foot-6 Joe Cooper. Then there's Kolt Byers, who proved to be one of the best athletes in the state after earning a gold medal in the high jump during the track and field season.

Byers, who also earned state medals in two other track and field events, is guaranteed to be a weapon for the Eagles wherever he plays this year. Last season, he scored four touchdowns and kicked 35 extra points for Bermudian.

Otherwise, it will be up to young players on the team to step up, particularly at the skill positions.

"The biggest story for us is what new faces are going to come along," DeFoe said.

Expectations: DeFoe is entering his third decade coaching high school football. He has been with the same coaching staff for at least 10 years.

That "consistency and cohesion" is important to Bermudian's success, DeFoe said.

Always in the conversation, Bermudian Springs earning its first league title since 2014 is among the team's goals.

DeFoe stated that there are two to three sophomores on the team who get the opportunity to showcase their talent this season.

"I think we're going to need something out of them," he said.

Despite the transition year, Bermudian Springs is expected to contend among the top teams in Division III ‚Äî York Catholic, Delone Catholic and Littlestown ‚Äî who also parted with excellent senior classes.

The longstanding belief in how the Eagles operate will not change in Year 21 for DeFoe

"Just plugging along, another year," DeFoe said.

search_result.title: IRS delays rule change for people who get paid on Venmo, Etsy ...
search_result.text:
New York CNN ‚Äî

Anyone getting paid for their goods and services through apps like Venmo, PayPal or CashApp, or platforms like Etsy and Airbnb, just got a reprieve from the IRS.

Following concerns expressed by the tax community, the electronic transactions industry and some lawmakers, the IRS said Friday it would delay by one year the implementation of a rule change that would have resulted in a virtual paper chase of tax forms going out by January 31, 2023, to anyone using such apps for their business transactions.

The rule change requires third-party payment platforms to issue a 1099-K to the IRS and the app user for business transaction payments if they add up to more than $600 over the course of the year. A business transaction that is taxable is defined as a payment for a good or service, including tips.

It used to be those platforms only had to issue you a 1099-K if you engaged in more than 200 business transactions for which you received total payments of more than $20,000 in a year.

‚ÄúThe IRS and Treasury heard a number of concerns regarding the timeline of implementation of these changes under the American Rescue Plan,‚Äù said Acting IRS Commissioner Doug O‚ÄôDonnell. ‚ÄúTo help smooth the transition and ensure clarity for taxpayers, tax professionals and industry, the IRS will delay implementation of the 1099-K changes. The additional time will help reduce confusion during the upcoming 2023 tax filing season and provide more time for taxpayers to prepare and understand the new reporting requirements.‚Äù

Indeed, the increase in 1099-Ks issued early next year for people‚Äôs 2022 tax returns was expected to be, in a word, ‚Äúginormous,‚Äù according to Wendy Walker, who chairs the information reporting subgroup on the Internal Revenue Service Advisory Council.

Walker works as a solution principal for Sovos, which helps more than 30,000 business clients with tax compliance, including the issuance of all types of 1099s, of which there are at least 16 different varieties.

Some businesses that only had to issue a couple thousand 1099-Ks under the prior rules were looking at a couple hundred thousand, she noted. ‚ÄúOur clients ‚Ä¶ have reported enormous increases in their potential filing obligations as result of the threshold change,‚Äù Walker said.

Meanwhile, those receiving 1099-Ks for the first time will have to figure out what portion of the amount reported on the form is actually taxable versus what portion represents payments that may be deductible business expenses, such as a fee paid to the payment platform or a credit issued to the business, Walker said.

‚ÄúPeople are just not going to understand how to take that gross amount and then work off the deductions to get to their taxable amount.‚Äù

Welcome news to companies having to issue tax forms

The move was welcomed by those representing third-party payment platforms.

‚ÄúGiven the potential confusion the reporting requirement would cause, we applaud the delay, ‚Äù said Scott Talbott, spokesman for the Electronic Transactions Association. ‚ÄúThe $600 reporting requirement is not worth the problems it would cause. ETA will keep working to increase the threshold to a realistic amount.‚Äù

How does ETA define realistic? A threshold that falls between $10,000 and $20,000, Talbott said. ‚ÄúETA supports a reporting threshold that ties into regular businesses and not consumers occasionally selling a handbag or a bike online.‚Äù

What the new rule doesn‚Äôt do

The new rule doesn‚Äôt impose any additional taxes on anyone. Nor does it change your obligation as a taxpayer to always report to the IRS all of your taxable income from your business activities.

But the 1099-K reporting will make it harder for someone to evade the taxes they owe by underreporting their business income.

The rule also does not apply to personal transactions you conduct on an electronic payment platform. For example, if a friend sends you money through Venmo to help pay for a dinner out or your mother sends you some spending money.

Lastly, the 1099-K reporting rule does not apply to any transactions made through Zelle. That‚Äôs because Zelle is a payments clearinghouse that connects the payer‚Äôs bank account directly to the receiver‚Äôs bank account. ‚ÄúZelle facilitates messaging between financial institutions, but does not hold accounts or handle settlement of funds,‚Äù the company said in a statement earlier this year.

But the IRS may still get reporting on at least some of your business transactions on Zelle, Walker said.

If there is a business-to-business payment over the Zelle network, the business that makes the payment must provide the receiving business and the IRS with either a 1099-NEC for non-employee compensation or a 1099-MISC for other expenses, she explained.

Like the 1099-K, those other forms also provide information to the IRS that will make it harder for businesses to understate their income in a tax year.

search_result.title: All-Big Bend cross country: FSU getting Runners of the Year Caitlin ...
search_result.text:
Five wins this cross country season was almost a foregone conclusion for Maclay senior Jay Brown. It was the complete opposite for Chiles senior Caitlin Wilkey.

Though each found their way path to season-long success in different ways, they share a couple unique traits.

Their dogged competitiveness and work ethic materialized quickly and didn‚Äôt let up, leading to area-leading times, district titles, and third-place state finishes.

Brown is the All-Big Bend Runner of the Year for the second straight season, while Wilkey ascends to the mantle of Runner of the Year won in previous years by teammates she emulated this season.

Continuing their united resume, both will graduate and become Florida State runners with skill sets ranging from middle distance on the track to longer racing in the woods.

FEATURED:Maclay's Brown, Chiles' Wilkey add more wins to senior cross-country seasons

‚ÄúWhen I think back on it, it was long in the moment, but the past three, four seasons in track, cross country, and baseball went by super fast,‚Äù Brown said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just excited for the next level.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt feels really great to get this honor after watching my two teammates get it the previous two years,‚Äù Wilkey said about current Mississippi State runner Ana Wallace and current Florida runner Emily Culley. ‚ÄúRunner of the Year is a really big deal and I‚Äôm really excited about it.‚Äù

Brown entered with huge expectations. He was the front-runner to win a Class 1A state title and only backed up those early projections with in-season results. As mentioned, he won five times, but he also ran sub-16:00 eight times this season after doing it just once last year.

He peaked with a 15:14 result at the prestigious Great American Cross Country Festival in North Carolina, took fourth at the FSU Invitational elite race a week later, and headed into the postseason ready to go for gold.

That didn‚Äôt materialize in the state race, but he was still 15 seconds faster than the third-place result he had as a junior. And now the double gold state champion from track season is angling to finish his senior year back on top.

2019 STATE TRACK:Maclay double gold winner Brown among area's top performances

2019 STATE XC ROUNDUP:Maclay, Leon celebrate high team, individual finishes

‚ÄúThe season as a whole wasn‚Äôt disappointing, it was just that one race that threw me off,‚Äù Brown said. ‚ÄúBut knowing I have track to back it up is super helpful. It fuels me to keep going and get better. I know I‚Äôm not at the top until I do more than I‚Äôve done.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not always a good thing to keep winning because you forget what losing was like, and you have no reason to win, you‚Äôre just doing it. This tells me I need to work a little harder than I did or do something else. There‚Äôs always room for change and to get better.‚Äù

Wilkey, by contrast, had never won a cross country race until this season. But an offseason dedicated to fitness, the same way Culley and Wallace transformed themselves before dominating senior seasons, upped Wilkey to a whole other level.

She won the first four races she competed in, heading into the FSU Invitational. There she broke 18:00 for the first time, running 17:54 to finish sixth in the girls elite race.

FSU INVITATIONAL:Cross country runners Churchill, Wilkey, Brown finish high in pre-state elite races

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know what to expect this season,‚Äù Wilkey said. ‚ÄúI knew I‚Äôd trained hard over the summer and had a good track season to set me up for some good success. I knew it would be a good season, I just didn‚Äôt know what to expect. But after the first two races, I knew it could be something special ‚Äì get some good times and win some races.

‚ÄúThe culture has definitely made an impact on my career and set the bar really high. It‚Äôs made me set goals higher than I thought I could make, and I‚Äôve reached them. I never thought I‚Äôd be here freshman year, so I‚Äôm really happy.‚Äù

It got even better after that.

Winning a district title and taking second at region, Wilkey headed back to Apalachee Regional Park and posted a 17:45 run at state to finish third as the Timberwolves finished state runner-up.

It was the third-best area time ever, trailing only Wallace and former Chiles great Lily Williams, and her state run was one second faster than Wallace's when she won a state title. Wilkey's four years yielded two state titles and two state runner-ups.

STATE XC:Chiles' girls cross country team captures Class 4A runner-up trophy at FHSAA state meet

WATCH:Chiles XC runner Caitlin Wilkey takes 3rd at state as Timberwolves get runner-up

‚ÄúCaitlin is so sweet, but she was tired of being in people‚Äôs shadows,‚Äù Timberwolves coach Mike Phillips said. ‚ÄúFor her to only trail Lily and Ana in Chiles‚Äô history is unbelievable.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs No. 2 in the 800, No. 3 in cross country, up there in the mile, and she hasn‚Äôt really embraced the two-mile, but clearly she‚Äôd be a great two-miler. She‚Äôs going to have an amazing track season and step over a lot of people again. She has the potential to be from top to bottom, the best overall. That‚Äôs saying a lot.‚Äù

Florida State is the recipient of our area‚Äôs greatness.

Brown will get to join up with the Seminoles and some close friends. Gabriel Curtis, who won the state title ahead of Brown last year while running for Mount Dora Christian, is there, as is former Chiles star Connor Phillips, who dueled head-to-head with Brown all last season.

‚ÄúGoing to FSU was a back-up plan in the beginning of my junior year, and I didn‚Äôt decide I wanted to go to FSU until two weeks before state (my senior year),‚Äù Brown said. ‚ÄúIt was just right timing. I had intentions of getting out of Tallahassee, going to the west coast or a super big school. I realized FSU had everything I wanted in Tallahassee. It‚Äôs the perfect place.‚Äù

Brown hopes to head into FSU with a couple more gold medals under his belt while lowering his track times.

Wilkey intends to do the same, and her and teammate Alyson Churchill, who will also run for the ‚ÄôNoles, will lead a super tough Timberwolves track contingent.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a dream to run for the home team,‚Äù Wilkey said. ‚ÄúI was willing to look at other options, and I did, but I felt like FSU was the best school and fit for me. It had the most to offer running and academically. I was really impressed.

‚ÄúChiles has just meant so much to me. Every year has been different but special. I have great memories with every single dynamic. I have really good memories from high school, so hopefully there will be good memories in college.‚Äù

Chiles‚Äô Phillips, Leon‚Äôs Wills honored as Coaches of the Year

Everyone knew historically what Chiles had done in previous season and that it would be vying for a third consecutive state title while moving up a class to Class 4A.

But the scoring was basically Wilkey and Churchill and the hope that others would materialize to aid the scoring.

In the end, Chiles finished as Class 4A state runner-up, but it came as seniors Megan Churchill and Emily Molen emerged to become first-team All-Big Bend runners for the first time, and the Timberwolves saw three sophomores and an unknown senior yield unexpected results to acquire another state trophy.

For his efforts building that achievement, third-year Chiles coach Mike Phillips has been named the 2019 All-Big Bend Coach of the Year in girls cross country.

‚ÄúIf anyone was really paying attention to our changes, I don‚Äôt think anyone would have given us a chance to get to second with only two known entities,‚Äù Phillips said. ‚ÄúBut we got a lot out of some young girls and some seniors were more consistent than they have been. They were replacing girls on back-to-back state championship teams, so I‚Äôm definitely proud of how those girls stepped up.

‚ÄúLast year, I knew it would be a really special team going in. This year, I thought we had a chance but everything would have to fall into place. I didn‚Äôt know what we were getting into going to 4A, but I knew we had two really good girls and then it was just a matter of whether other girls would step up, and they did. It was gratifying to get those girls to buy into the hard work needed to be in that starting role.‚Äù

For the first time since 2012, veteran Leon coach Andrew Willis the boys All-Big Bend Coach of the Year.

It hasn‚Äôt been a total dry spell since then, but the runner-up seasons just happened to come at times when Chiles‚Äô boys won it all.

But prior years were rough, and Leon even saw its 10-year state appearance streak end.

That wasn‚Äôt the case this year. Led by sophomore Jackson Yarbrough, freshman Jake Rogers, and senior Bryson Gonzalez ‚Äì all first-team runners this season ‚Äì the Lions not only beat Chiles head-to-head several times, but they won district and regional titles before finishing third in Class 3A.

POSTSEASON:Resurgent Leon boys and girls cross country teams win District 1-3A titles

MORE:Maclay cross country wins two regional titles; Leon's boys, Chiles' girls grab firsts

‚ÄúIt re-energizes you and provides a little more purpose,‚Äù Wills said. ‚ÄúIf they want it, you want it. And it‚Äôs our job to make them want it, too. It‚Äôs just more fun when you‚Äôre competitive. We had years with a lull, now we‚Äôre getting back to the top.

‚ÄúI thought we would be pretty competitive. We‚Äôd threw top three around as a what if, but I think they outperformed our expectations. The younger kids developed, and the returners exceeded expectations. It was a fun season.‚Äù
