search_result.title: Overworked, underpaid? The toll of burnout is contributing to ...
search_result.text:
New data shows teacher shortages remain just as widespread as they were in the summer, though the average number of vacancies has slightly declined.

The scale of the problem varies significantly by region, district, school, subject and grade level. Many areas have all the teachers they need.

The pay and pressures of the job are major ‚Äì though hardly the only ‚Äì reasons some schools are struggling to fill certain teaching positions.

Several years ago, Naomi Norman, superintendent of Washtenaw Intermediate School District in Michigan, had a conversation that changed her perspective on the needs of the teaching profession. It was with a special education teaching assistant adored by the school community and a natural at working with children with complex learning needs.

Special education teachers were, and remain, hard to come by. The field needed people precisely like this paraprofessional to fill those roles, Norman thought, so why hadn‚Äôt he considered pursuing a degree to become a professional teacher?

The aide explained he was the breadwinner for a family of five children and already working a second job to make do. He couldn‚Äôt afford to quit his day job, give up health insurance and go back to school, much less pay the tuition. Michigan is on the lower end when it comes to paraprofessional pay, with an average salary of less than $27,000, according to ZipRecruiter data.

The aide ended up leaving the education sector altogether soon after that. It‚Äôs become one of Norman‚Äôs missions to reduce such barriers into, and turnover from, the profession.

Fast-forward to the pandemic era: Special education teachers are even harder to come by, many of those barriers remain intact, and headlines have warned for months about catastrophic school staffing shortages nationwide.

Norman‚Äôs experience offers a glimpse into why vacancies have remained so stubborn at some schools. Here‚Äôs what you need to know about the state of teacher shortages, now that schools are close to halfway done with the school year.

Remote learning took its toll:The teacher shortages are just piling on.

Is there truly a teacher shortage?

There is no national teacher shortage. Many classrooms have all the educators they need and in some cases never had vacancies to begin with.

Yet shortages in many others persist. Staffing levels can vary significantly by state, district, school, subject and grade level.

The National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) has been regularly surveying a nationally representative sample of schools about various topics, including staff vacancies, in the COVID-19 era. According to its latest School Pulse Panel survey, from October, nearly half (45%) of public schools have at least one vacant teaching position, about the same rate as when the survey was done in January. The average number of vacancies per school, however, dropped from slightly more than three in June to two this October.

Generally speaking, 4% of teaching positions across the nation remained vacant, the October survey shows. But zooming in by subject area reveals significant variation.

Special education continues to have it worst, with 7% of positions unfilled. English-language-learning programs are also especially understaffed (6%), as is computer science (5%). Areas with the fewest vacancies: social studies and English/language arts, at just 2% each.

Is there a teacher shortage? Here's what the data says.

Why are there shortages of teachers?

Myriad reasons: low pay and morale, mounting political and academic pressures, health and safety concerns. A generation of teachers hitting or nearing retirement and another generation of prospective teachers deterred by the profession‚Äôs flailing reputation and the sacrifices it necessitates.

‚ÄúWe all know that our educators work very hard, and it‚Äôs not news to anyone that they often work beyond their required hours,‚Äù said NCES Commissioner Peggy Carr in a news briefing announcing results of a separate survey of teachers and principals. It showed teachers and principals work 52 hours and 58 hours a week on average, respectively.

According to that same survey, 17% of teachers work elsewhere at another job.

There are also hurdles to joining the workforce, like those Norman, the Washtenaw school district superintendent in Ann Arbor, Michigan, described.

Some state and district leaders are working to remove them, including a newly formed consortium of Michigan school systems aiming to bolster the pipeline into teaching. Norman is helping spearhead the initiative and piloting a grow-your-own program in her district, a regional agency that oversees the county‚Äôs special education services. The program has thus far paid three cohorts of 25 paraprofessionals each to earn teaching degrees and become certified special education teachers while continuing to work.

The program has created a ‚Äúnatural network‚Äù of professionals who can fill the area‚Äôs perennial special education vacancies, Norman said. But ‚Äúit‚Äôs not just a position filled. It‚Äôs a person supported. They're walking into that role with a huge net of support around them.‚Äù

Lack of such support has been another big reason some schools struggle to fill positions. COVID-19 aside, these challenges are not new ‚Äì nor are some of the shortages.

Which states have the worst teacher shortages right now?

It‚Äôs hard to say definitively. States don‚Äôt collect all the necessary data in a consistent, comprehensive or timely manner. One recent working paper analyzed available data and found that vacancies were particularly pronounced in Florida, Illinois and Arizona.

If national labor figures are any indication, teacher turnover has remained relatively stable since before the pandemic. But those statistics obscure what‚Äôs happening on the ground in many communities.

Another recent working paper focused on Tennessee, examining data from the beginning of 2019-20. Relatively few schools had vacancies, but the ones that did were spread throughout the state ‚Äì most regions had at least one school with positions they couldn‚Äôt fill.

Test scores fell during the pandemic:How did your state fare?

How are teacher shortages affecting students?

Shortages tend to be worse in low-income areas. Fifty-seven percent of high-poverty schools that participated in the October School Pulse Panel reported at least one teaching vacancy, including well over a third with multiple openings. The same was true for 41% of low-poverty schools, less than a quarter of which reported multiple vacancies.

Similar disparities emerge when looking at the racial composition of schools. Sixty percent of those where at least three-quarters of students are people of color have one or more vacancies, compared with less than a third of those where at least three-quarters of students are white.

That means the shortages are concentrated at schools whose students were hit hardest by the academic disruptions of the pandemic.

In other words, the children arguably most in need of qualified teachers are also most likely to attend schools who don‚Äôt have enough.

Keep reading USA TODAY's education reporting in 2023 for more on teachers and the teaching profession.

Contact Alia Wong at (202) 507-2256 or awong@usatoday.com. Follow her on Twitter at @aliaemily.

search_result.title: Local political expert takes look at Illinois governor race
search_result.text:
In about 100 days, the leaves will be crunching, and Election Day 2022 will be here in Illinois. On Nov. 8, Republican challenger and state Sen. Darren Bailey, R-Xenia, will face Democratic Gov. JB Pritzker in a race mired with major issues and big money.

Kent Redfield, a retired professor with the University of Illinois and the Institute for Government and Public Affairs, sees a race playing along three regions in the state: Chicago, downstate and the suburbs.

Two regions ‚àí Chicago and downstate ‚àí are essentially wrapped up for Pritzker and Bailey respectively. The battleground areas, Redfield says, are the suburbs primarily in the collar counties surrounding Chicago.

"You can make a difference there," he said. "You can grow or shrink."

More:8-year-old boy and 3-year-old girl die after families contacted by Illinois DCFS

At a press conference held earlier this week, Bailey stood before the Department of Children and Family Services building to, as he put it, to "discuss problems." This tactic, one where he attacked Pritzker and DCFS Director Marc Smith for the department's shortcomings, is the playbook Redfield projects will carry out in months to come.

"Bailey wants people to focus on what are the specific problems in terms of governing in Illinois and what are Pritzker's failings," he said.

A similar strategy was used by former Republican Gov. Bruce Rauner, said Redfield, whose campaign attacking Democrat weaknesses lead to the unseating of then-Gov. Pat Quinn in 2014.

What he will try to avoid is past comments on abortion, where he previously supported a complete ban before backing away from that stance.

The overturning of Roe v. Wadeby the Supreme Court and ongoing legislation efforts regarding marriage equality and contraceptives could energize women's rights and LGBTQ+ groups around Pritzker, Redfield said.

Redfield said Pritzker also will continue trying to portray Bailey, endorsed by former President Donald Trump, as radical. Such was the method of primary ads from the Democratic Governors Association which labeled the Republican candidate as "too extreme."

During that conference, points of emphasis made by Bailey included high numbers vacant positions within DCFS, improper vaccination protocols, and two deaths ‚àí one 8-year-old boy and one 3-year-old girl ‚àí that after DCFS contacted the families.

"I don't know what world that JB lives in, but this is not progress," said Bailey on Tuesday in front of the DCFS building on Monroe Street. "This is incompetence of tragic proportions."

The State Journal-Register attempted to speak with the candidate to discuss how the department would operate if he was elected. After several phone calls, emails and text messages, there was no response.

Bailey sits on the state Child Care Accessibility & Early Childhood Education Committee, which received a $142 million request from DCFS in the previous legislative session to "do their job more adequately," he said.

According to Bailey, the department would already have $12 million unspent by the end of Fiscal Year 2022, which ended July 1. In FY 2021, DCFS had a remainder of $28 million unspent.

"That is gross negligence," said Bailey. "I asked the question 'Where this money went?' I got no reply. I asked the question 'Why it wasn't spent?' I got no reply."

"This administration under Marc Smith's leadership has failed not only the organization, but the families and children in this state."

Bailey's chances of working with DCFS as governor, however, are met with him trailing in campaign funds and recent post-primary poll numbers.

The Republican had less than $365,000 in his campaign fund as of June 28, per filings submitted to the Illinois Board of Elections. Pritzker, who is financing his own campaign, had $60.8 million available in the his most recent filing as of July 15.

According to Victory Research, Pritzker also holds a near 10-point lead over Bailey in its poll released last week and dominating the Chicago area.

Of those surveyed, 78% in Chicago said they would vote for Pritzker compared to 13% choosing Bailey. The Republican challenger, however had leads in the central, western and southern parts of the state.

Bailey, who has referred to Chicago as a "hellhole," did however pick up an endorsement from John Catanzara, president of Fraternal Order of Police Lodge 7, on Wednesday.

search_result.title: Why police forces are struggling to recruit and keep officers | CNN
search_result.text:
Durham, North Carolina CNN ‚Äî

In a growing number of American cities, if you call the police, there are fewer officers taking the call.

Police departments across the nation are raising concerns about current and future staffing levels. CNN reached out to nearly 20 departments nationwide, along with other key stakeholders including elected officials, union officials and outside recruiters for departments for this story.

They all point to similar concerns including Covid-19, the great resignation, the climate for law enforcement and local reform efforts that are making recruitment and retention difficult.

The challenges have led the chief of police in Durham, North Carolina, to join her officers in patrolling her own city. The department is down 90 officers out of a budgeted force of 627. The department has started to offer a $5,000 bonus for new hires to fill its ranks.

Durham, North Carolina, Police Department Headquarters. CNN

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been tough,‚Äù Chief Patrice Andrews said of the current staffing issues facing her city. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve had to be very creative with staffing, you know, putting investigators and those that typically wouldn‚Äôt necessarily be taking 911 calls, putting them back on the street.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe 911 calls don‚Äôt stop. People are still having emergencies, the emergencies don‚Äôt stop and certainly the emergencies don‚Äôt care if you are 60% staffed or below,‚Äù Andrews told CNN while she was on patrol. ‚ÄúThis profession is, is something we were all called to do and not everyone is meant to be the police. This profession is certainly a noble one, even yet and still, despite everything, this profession is certainly noble.‚Äù

A national survey from June of 2021 found that departments around the country on average were filling 93% of budgeted positions available, according to the Police Executive Research Forum.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got a workforce that‚Äôs being compressed on the front end, you‚Äôve got a drop in people who want to be cops. And on the other end, you have a significant increase in people who are resigning and retiring. And we have a survey that we did (that found a) 44% increase in retirements, 18% increase in resignations (in police departments),‚Äù according to Police Executive Research Forum President Chuck Wexler.

On average, officers spend 8 months training before they can patrol the streets alone, according to the Bureau of Justice Statistics. Meaning, it will take years to fill the open jobs at departments across the country, Wexler said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a trying time to be a police officer in this country,‚Äù Wexler said. ‚ÄúSo, police chiefs are wondering who are going to be the cops of the future.‚Äù

Departments are also struggling daily to cover those out sick due to Covid-19, and higher rates of crime, Wexler and several departments said.

In Philadelphia, the department is down 440 officers or 7% of the number of police officers budgeted for the city, the department told CNN.

‚ÄúWell, right now it‚Äôs not a very desirable job,‚Äù John McNesby, head of the Philadelphia Fraternal Order of Police (FOP), told CNN. ‚ÄúEverything that‚Äôs been going on around the country for the last couple of years. ‚Ä¶ But right now, I mean just getting people to apply is a monster in itself.‚Äù

During a recent recruitment event, 600 people said they would attend, only 200 showed up and only 26 moved on to the physical assessment phases, McNesby said. The FOP also points to a recently passed requirement that requires all applicants to have lived in the city for at least a year, as an additional challenge to find new officers in the city of brotherly love.

In Atlanta, which like many cities in America also saw unrest in the wake of the murder of George Floyd, two incidents of police use of force also put pressure on the local community. Community outreach events like Clippers and Cops, held in local barbershops around the city, are trying to ‚Äúbridge the gap‚Äù between the community and the police. The events allow officers to open a dialogue between themselves and the citizens who they serve and protect, participants say.

Atlanta Police Chief Rodney Bryant, left, with Atlanta Mayor Andre Dickens. CNN

During an appearance at the event this month, Andre Dickens, the newly elected mayor of Atlanta, said he is working to get the police department back to full strength.

‚ÄúThe goal is to be smart on crime, and so we have to have a balanced approach to safety and justice,‚Äù Dickens said. ‚ÄúThat means getting more officers in because we lost about 400 to 500 officers over the past three years. So I‚Äôm trying to get those 400 officers back, but training them in conflict resolution and skills on how to de-escalate issues so that they can be better community-based cops.‚Äù

The mayor said a number of issues contributed to the decrease in the rank and file. ‚ÄúThere was a morale challenge across the last couple of years with Covid and with a lot of issues related to police, excessive use of force that went unchecked, but then ‚Ä¶ everybody said get rid of police and these sorts of things,‚Äù Dickens said.

Tyrone Dennis CNN

The founder of Clippers and Cops was one of those 400 officers who left the department. Detective Tyrone Dennis retired from the force in August 2020, moved back to St. Louis, Missouri, to be with his family and took a job as a director of school safety, a job that paid more than being a police officer.

‚ÄúThey got to do better with pay ‚Ä¶ incentives to retain officers,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt would be foolish for me to stay for $48,000. When I have a wife and three kids to feed for $48,000. I can almost qualify for public assistance. That‚Äôs not cool,‚Äù Dennis said.

‚ÄúBasically we‚Äôre one bullet away from death, and one mistake away from indictment so why roll the dice with my future when I can go do something else?‚Äù Dennis said.

Police leadership also say that pay should be more in line with work requirements. ‚ÄúWhen you think of what the line of work calls for and what they‚Äôre having to do, they‚Äôre wanting to be compensated, you know, but also to they‚Äôve got to be able to support their families. You know, we have officers that can‚Äôt even qualify for apartments because their, their income doesn‚Äôt match up with what the apartments require. That‚Äôs a problem,‚Äù Andrews said.

In Phoenix, the police department is sending detectives and officers from various specialty assignments to patrol. Last month, the department started to take additional reports virtually rather than send officers out, police department spokesperson Sgt. Andy Williams told CNN.

The police department is down 13% of its allotment of officers, according to data provided by Phoenix Police to CNN.

It is offering hiring bonuses of up to $8,700 dollars for new hires with college degrees, the department said.

In Winston-Salem, North Carolina, Police Chief Catriana A. Thompson says the situation is ‚Äúalarming.‚Äù The department is down 96 officers or 18% of its allotted force. Some of the department‚Äôs ‚Äúspecialized units have been disbanded temporarily until staffing levels improve,‚Äù Thompson told CNN in a statement.

Reliant Hiring Solutions, a firm that works with law enforcement around the country to set up job fairs, said it was more difficult to find recruits in more ‚Äúliberal cities,‚Äù Randall Blanchard, told CNN.

In Seattle, the department is experiencing ‚Äúunprecedented‚Äù losses of staff, the department told CNN. The department is short more than 225 officers or 17% of its workforce.

‚ÄúOur losses over the last two years have been unprecedented,‚Äù police department spokesperson Sgt. Randy Hyserik told CNN. ‚ÄúMany of our newer officers separated from our department and moved to smaller agencies in the area, and some left law enforcement altogether. In their exit interviews, many cited the ‚Äòdefund‚Äô movement and a lack of support from local elected officials as their reason for leaving our department, or for leaving law enforcement completely.‚Äù

Seattle‚Äôs attrition rate has over doubled in the last two years. Prior to 2020, the annual attrition rate was 70 to 75 officers a year. The department has had 356 officers leave over the last two years, according to data provided to CNN by the department.

People that call police for non-life-threatening calls may have to wait longer for a response, unless staffing levels are improved, ‚Äúyou may be lucky if you get an officer 2, 3, 4 hours down the line,‚Äù McNesby said.

‚ÄúI mean it‚Äôs easier for me to sit here and talk about it,‚Äù McNesby said, ‚Äúbut it really affects the people standing at roll calls in the morning when they look to the left and look to the right and there‚Äôs nobody else there ‚Ä¶ or you have a citizen that‚Äôs on the line ‚Ä¶ where they feel the need for police attention and they dial 911 and you‚Äôre not getting anybody coming.‚Äù

search_result.title: Challenge begins to find leader for mental health hospital
search_result.text:
Mark Walker

Argus Leader

State officials have started a nationwide search for the next administrator of South Dakota's primary mental health hospital.

In mid-June, after a little more than a year on the job, Human Services Center administrator Troy Jones announced his resignation for personal and family reasons.

Stability is what the embattled hospital needs. It has suffered from high turnover in a number of positions for years, including its top leadership role.

Jones‚Äô departure leaves state officials searching for the HSC's fourth administrator since 2011. Cory Nelson left the post in 2011. Ric Compton was named administrator of the hospital in 2012 but resigned from the position three years later.

‚Äú(The Department of Social Services) is looking for an experienced leader who will be able to create an environment and culture that enables the hospital to fulfill its mission and ensure patients are receiving the best possible care,‚Äù said Tia Kafka, a spokeswoman for the Department of Social Services, which oversees the hospital.

Kafka said the department will accept applications from across the country for its vacant spot, as well as a qualified candidate to serve as interim director until the position is permanently filled.

But the hiring process has its hurdles. Before Jones' arrival, the administrative position had been open for about a year.

‚ÄúStates do face challenges in recruiting for this key leadership position, especially in rural areas,‚Äù Kafka said.

More:Trauma & Turnover: State Mental Health Hospital Investigation

Former HSC administrator David Bean agreed that selling a high-qualified candidate on living in Yankton, with a population of about 15,000, could pose challenges.

Bean said he‚Äôd prefer to see the state hire someone similar to Jones, who had previous experience as a hospital administrator at a psychiatric hospital. He said trying to uplift a facility that's experienced some troubles could be a daunting task for a person who isn‚Äôt qualified for the position.

Phyllis Arends, executive director of National Alliance on Mental Illness in Sioux Falls, said she also wants to see an administrator who has previously run a facility. But, she said, the ideal candidate would also have a clinical background as well.

A dearth of mental health professionals in South Dakota contributed to the problems Jones was tasked with trying to fix during his tenure at HSC. The state legislature last year approved a raise for entry-level workers at the state-run hospital in hopes putting Jones in a better position to fill the vacancies.

‚ÄúIn South Dakota, it is well known that we have a terrible work force shortage in the mental health field," Arends said. ‚ÄúSo having to reach out beyond the wall of our communities and state needs to be done.‚Äù

More:Administrator resigns after one year at S.D. mental health hospital

An Argus Leader Media investigation in 2016 showed workers leaving the state hospital at a rate of about one every three days since July 2008. The number of employees injured by patients has gone up in three of four years, peaking at 222 in the fiscal year 2014. The high turnover was also coupled with low employee morale and violence against employees.

A hiring fair was held in October to fill the dozens of open positions they had which included mental health aides, nurses and counselors. Several hires were made but the pool of employees in Yankton can only produce so many potential employees.

Bean said whomever takes over the facilities will still have to work toward finding enough qualified personnel to run the hospital.

‚ÄúThe major challenges are always getting an adequate number of staff," Bean said. "And paying adequate salaries for staff."

search_result.title: Job seekers share their search stories in tough COVID-19 market
search_result.text:
Editor's note: This is Part 2 of a four-part series looking at how businesses and laborers are navigating a worker shortage.

Kim Porter spent more than a year trying to find a job comparable to the one she lost due to the pandemic.

Had it not been for a friendly connection with Sundee Porter (no relation) of Holmes County Job and Family Services, the Green resident still might be looking for work.

Job and Family Services and OhioMeansJobs.com are one path job seekers may use as they try to find a position that fulfills their career objectives.

Ohio's unemployment rate was 5.4% in July, up from 5.2% in June, with 301,000 workers jobless, according to state Department of Job and Family Services data. While there are plenty of jobs available across Ohio, finding a secure, high-paying position with advancement opportunities can be challenging.

Porter, whose job search is ongoing, and another local resident who found a new career path, share their stories.

Workers Part 1:A worker shortage already existed for most industries, the pandemic made it worse

Find jobs:Ashland, Holmes, and Wayne work together to help unemployed find jobs in a new industry

Getting on track to finding a job

Porter had nearly three decades of experience in management and administration when she lost her job at Med Spa in Green when COVID-19 led to the shutdown of many businesses.

She's working part time at a Med Spa in Cleveland while she looks for full-time employment.

"Since losing my job in March of 2020, getting interviews has been the hardest part; getting people to stand up and pay attention to my experience."

She sent out hundreds of resumes and went on roughly 10 interviews.

"When you've been in the workforce as long as I have, it's frustrating," Porter said. "I have 30 years experience, and some people don't want to pay for that. I was pretty open and flexible about salary for the most part, and I think the fact that I'm pushing 60 might have had something to do with it."

Porter didn't mind commuting 30 minutes but finding a full-time position with benefits proved difficult.

"I've got all this experience in management. It was tough to go from making $5,000 a month to nothing," she said.

Porter broadened her horizons, and was willing to try a new field, but she felt more comfortable working in the health care industry.

She was getting nowhere with the unemployment bureau in Summit County and had no money coming in.

"A friend of mine, who had also been laid off, connected me with Sundee at Holmes JFS," Porter said. "She's been like a godsend to me. I don't think I would've seen anything from unemployment if it hadn't been for her."

Job and Family Services helped her get unemployment benefits while she continues to work part time and look for job opportunities.

Her takeaway from the job search: "Keep pushing forward and not take (rejection) personal and feel less than I am."

Yes, jobs are plentiful, but some hold out for meaningful work

Teretta Swartzentruber, of Wooster, found herself alone and unemployed as the pandemic was beginning.

The 49-year-old let the system work for her, and now she is her own boss.

Swartzentruber had moved to Ohio about 10 years ago. She was married and was not in the workforce. Later, she got a part-time job in retail.

The store where she worked shut down during the early stages of the pandemic. Swartzentruber divorced during that time and turned to unemployment.

Through Ohio Job and Family Services in Wooster she learned there was a need for health care workers, "but I wasn't going to go to school to be a nurse."

"I looked into home health care, where it seemed there was a big need," she said.

A state grant helped her pay for classes to become a certified state tested nursing assistant (STNA). Swartzentruber said she worked for a company 180 days then applied through Medicare for a license to provide home health care.

Around the first of April, Swartzentruber began working for herself and makes her own hours working with her clients to accommodate their needs. She gets paid directly through the government.

"I've come a long way," she said. "I did my research and was diligent in doing my homework to find this career, but help was right here all along."

Finding the money for classes and training was one of the biggest hurdles she had to overcome. Swartzentruber said she wanted to find a meaningful career in a stable field.

"I am so proud of where I am and what the county did for me. I want people to know that help is out there," Swartzentruber said. "I had no income when I was out of work, so I got food stamps. That really helped. I was able to pack my lunch and go to school and take classes. I didn't want to ever be on it, but I am grateful it was there when I needed it."

Reach Kevin at klynch@the-daily-record.com

search_result.title: Cape Cod first responder shortage highlights town hiring difficultes
search_result.text:
Staff reports

When Barnstable Police Chief Matt Sonnabend recently talked to the town council about his department's budget, he mentioned he had eight staff vacancies.

"Hiring is a struggle right now," he said.

And that applies pretty much everywhere on Cape Cod. Local communities are among 86% of cities and towns nationwide having trouble attracting first responders. For the Cape, the problem is tied to the high price of housing.

search_result.title: Two children die after families contacted by Illinois DCFS
search_result.text:
Beth Hundsdorfer

Capitol News Illinois

Peoria County Coroner Jamie Harwood admits he has seen a lot of horrible things in his 20 years as an emergency room nurse in Chicago trauma centers and five years he has served as county coroner. But he said he has never seen a worse case of child abuse and neglect than he saw Tuesday.

Harwood was the coroner in the case of 8-year-old Navin Jones, who died Tuesday evening at OSF Healthcare St. Francis Medical Center in Peoria. Navin was in the care of the Illinois Department of Children and Family Services, but his body was found at his parents‚Äô home. Jones‚Äô family had been in contact with DCFS before his death, according to DCFS spokesman William McCaffrey.

Stephanie Jones, 35, and Brandon Walker, 40, Navin‚Äôs parents, face first-degree murder charges in connection with the boy‚Äôs death.

More:Peoria boy, 8, weighed 30 pounds, had signs of physical abuse when he died, prosecutor says

‚ÄúI think there should be a hefty internal investigation by DCFS into this case,‚Äù Harwood said. ‚ÄúAnd if there were failures, those should be remedied.‚Äù

The Peoria Journal Star reported Peoria County State‚Äôs Attorney Dave Kenny said during the arraignment for Navin‚Äôs parents that the boy weighed 30 pounds and was living in deplorable conditions. The child was last seen in late October or early November, when he was in ‚Äúrelatively good health,‚Äù according to the newspaper report.

Harwood declined to comment on Navin‚Äôs condition at the time of his death, citing the pending investigation, but did say the cause of his death was homicide and the manner was abuse and neglect.

Eighty miles due north of Peoria in Nelson, another coroner was investigating the death of 3-year-old Tamsin Miracle Sauer. She died in a Sterling hospital in Whiteside County on Saturday. The manner and cause of her death is still under investigation.

Tamsin‚Äôs family also had contact with DCFS, McCaffrey said.

Earlier story:DCFS Director Marc Smith held in contempt of court for 7th time in 10 weeks

Agency says it is aggressively hiring

Also on Tuesday, DCFS Director Marc Smith filed the first annual report on the department‚Äôs plan to address investigator caseloads as a requirement of a federal consent decree. That report, filed in a court document, showed there is a current statewide rolling vacancy percentage of 21 percent, and DCFS has a goal of reducing it to 6 percent or less.

DCFS stated in the report that it is aggressively hiring, having added 198 investigators to the payroll since March 2021, but due to the high number of employees leaving and retiring, the overall headcount went up by only a dozen investigators.

The agency pointed to the COVID-19 pandemic and a labor crisis, coupled with rising child abuse investigations across the state, as obstacles to meeting that goal.

Cook County Public Guardian Charles Golbert, whose office represents about 7,100 children in state care, said Thursday that if DCFS had been keeping up with hiring over the past few decades it would not be in such straits now.

‚ÄúIt's clear that when DCFS's investigators labor under untenable caseloads without the supports that they need, in violation of court orders, both children and the investigators alike are at risk of serious harm and even death,‚Äù Golbert said in a phone call. ‚ÄúI fear that until DCFS gets its investigator caseloads down to reasonable levels, as mandated under a federal court order that is now more than 30 years old, we will continue to see children harmed.‚Äù

Golbert also mentioned the January death of DCFS investigator Deidre Silas as an impediment to hiring.

‚ÄúIf the investigators have caseloads that are too high, that‚Äôs dangerous for kids and for workers,‚Äù Golbert said.

In the motion filed by DCFS on Tuesday, the 12-month average of investigations in March 2021 was 6,535. That rose to 7,726 in March 2022. An increase in reporting may be attributable to children having more contact with mandated reporters, such as teachers and doctors, as the pandemic eases. The increase may also be attributable to an increase in family stress, such as financial pressures.

More:After homicide of Peoria boy, investigation reopened into half-brother's death

In addition to recruiting and retention efforts, DCFS is conducting weekend ‚Äúblitzes,‚Äù moving staff from other locations to volunteer for weekend shifts to help with completing investigations. In DCFS‚Äôs northern region, the agency conducted 13 blitzes where 148 staff worked a combined 2,500 weekend hours to help with investigations.

Last year, the court granted a three-year extension to DCFS to meet caseworker hiring goals. The parties agreed to make changes in 1991, but 30 years later the agency is still struggling to be in full compliance with the decree.

The deaths of Navin and Tamsin are the latest cases of children who have died after having contact with DCFS. Since January, Sophia Faye Davis, 1; Damari Perry, 6; and Zaraz Walker, 7 months, have died from child abuse.

Director faces eight contempt charges

In addition, DCFS Director Smith has faced eight contempt of court citations from a Cook County Judge. The contempt citations are based on improper placements for children in state care.

Last week, Smith was cited for contempt for the eighth time from Cook County Circuit Judge Patrick Murphy.

The latest case involves a 14-year-old girl who entered DCFS care in September. She has been in 21 placements in her time with DCFS, according to a release by the Cook County Public Guardian‚Äôs Office. Those placements included time in a locked psychiatric ward, hospital emergency rooms, emergency foster homes and, most recently, in a temporary shelter. In December, DCFS recommended a residential placement for the girl.

In two of the eight cases, the contempt order was purged when the children were placed in their recommended setting. Those two cases involved:

* An 8-year-old girl placed in a locked psychiatric hospital unnecessarily for more than seven months.

* A 13-year-old boy kept in a ‚Äútemporary‚Äù shelter in Mount Vernon ‚Äì nearly five hours away from his family ‚Äì for nearly five months. Before the shelter, DCFS placed him in a utility room in an office.

In the other five previous cases, the contempt order remains in place and the children remain in their present settings. Those cases involve:

* A 17-year-old boy who was placed in a locked psychiatric hospital for more than four months beyond medical necessity.

* A 16-year-old girl housed in 25 different places in two months, including hospitals, emergency shelters, a shelter in Indiana, and temporary foster homes. Before that, she was in a locked psychiatric hospital for nearly two months after it was recommended that she be moved.

* An 11-year-old girl medically approved for discharge from a locked psychiatric hospital for nearly a year waiting for a transfer to a residential placement.

* A 15-year-old girl placed in a locked psychiatric hospital since Dec. 6, 2021 ‚Äì approximately three months waiting for transfer to a specialized foster home.

* A 16-year-old boy who spent more than 375 days in a temporary shelter that was unable to meet his highly specialized needs given his low intellectual function.

Each of the seven children in these cases is represented by the Cook County public guardian‚Äôs office. The orders for contempt were signed by Judge Murphy, who served for 25 years as the Cook County Public Guardian.

Harwood, the coroner in Navin‚Äôs case, knows about DCFS. He and his husband became foster parents in 2017 and eventually adopted his son, Jacob, who was taken into state care after he was born prematurely to a mother who struggled with addiction.

When Jacob‚Äôs biological mother died from drug exposure months after his birth, Harwood was the responding coroner. Harwood said he‚Äôs troubled by the death of the 8-year-old who died in his county Tuesday, while grateful for his own son, who was once a state ward.

‚ÄúWe were lucky. He is our miracle,‚Äù Harwood said.

search_result.title: Springfield Police Department still reeling from effects of 2020 hiring ...
search_result.text:
The city had an opportunity to hire 16 police officers in September 2020 but didn't because of economic uncertainties. Now, the Springfield Police Department is looking to hire another 15 in January as its staffing level is double-digit percentage points below its desired roster size.

SPD Chief Kenny Winslow said he now has the green light from Springfield Mayor Jim Langfelder to hire as many officers as possible. But a competitive market and slow hiring and onboarding process has continued to put the department in a staffing bind.

In his quarterly report to the Springfield City Council, Winslow said SPD has had to essentially "cannibalize" every unit and shift rotation to use the most of its staff, which has 194 active and 30 inactive officers, according to preliminary quarterly numbers, well below the desired staffing level of 250.

More:Out on Adams officially opens; proceeds from LGBTQ merchandise will benefit Phoenix Center

"We're constantly hiring and recruiting," Winslow said, calling it a 365-day-a-year process. He compared it to colleges recruiting athletes, saying that SPD has to showcase incentives to compete with other departments from what is becoming a smaller and smaller recruiting class.

A mixture of political factors and economic ramifications from the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, which has contributed to shortages in a plethora of industries, has resulted in a smaller and smaller recruiting for SPD to choose candidates from. It most recently sent a class of 14 to a regional police academy. Winslow said SPD hoped to send 16 for training but two candidates backed out.

"There's a lot of guys, girls internalizing what they see on social media, what they see on TV and say 'I'm out,'" Winslow said, speaking to growing calls for accountability and oversight into local police departments in light of a renewed nationwide focus into systemic racism and police brutality.

More:Top 5 takeaways from Week 9 of Illinois high school football in Springfield

Regardless of the external factors, Winslow said he's confident SPD will be able to put together a full recruiting class and that the department will be able to slowly grow and return to pre-pandemic staffing levels.

Internally, Winslow recognized that if the city knew in fall 2020 the immediate economic outlook, particularly how much money Springfield would get from the federal American Rescue Plan Act, it would've likely hired 16 officers from a recruiting class that season and they would currently be in a lot better position staffing-wise.

In order to avoid layoffs, payouts and furloughs, Langfelder asked several city departments not to hire candidates due to economic uncertainties. There was no firm timetable of a COVID-19 vaccine in fall 2020 and the election season and other political factors raised uncertainty over how much stimulus dollars the federal government was going to pump into local governments.

More:Growing Illinois sports betting market is now keeping company with top states like Nevada

Quarterly report

SPD released its preliminary numbers through June on arrests, shootings and other relevant figures compared to the same time in 2020:

Gun-related arrests were up more than 36% in 2021 through June compared to that same time in 2020. A total of 175 adults and 23 minors were arrested in 2021 for some gun-related offense, according to preliminary numbers from the report.

Common crimes such as theft, burglary and robbery were collectively down a few percentage points through June compared to that same timeframe in 2020.

Fifty-seven people were confirmed shot in Springfield through September, 20 more than the same time in 2020. Combined, 23 people were shot in January, February and March compared to a total of seven confirmed shooting victims in those months in 2020.

You might like:Springfield family buys 3 more historic buildings in the city

"During the pandemic ... we've shown some improvements in some areas," Langfelder said responding to the quarterly numbers. "The number of guns being taken off the streets is encouraging but discouraging at the same time."

SPD has already confiscated more guns, 304, in 2021 than it has in total in any year since at least 2016, per the report.

SPD is collecting online applications through 11 p.m. Wednesday at springfield.il.us/Departments/HumanResources/PoliceRecruitment.aspx. A physical and written exam testing period is scheduled for Friday.
